{{main|1999 Fed Cup}}
The '''Americas Zone''' was one of three zones of regional competition in the [[1999 Fed Cup]].
==Group I== *Venue: Buenos Aires T.C., [[Buenos Aires]], [[Argentina]] (outdoor clay) *Date: 13‚Äì18 April
The ten teams were randomly divided into two pools of five teams to compete in round-robin competitions. The teams that finished first in the pools played-off to determine which team would partake in the [[1999 Fed Cup#World Group II Play-offs|World Group II Play-offs]], while the teams that finished last in the pools would be relegated to Group II for 2000.
===Pools=== {{col-float-begin|width=35em}} {{5TeamRR | title=[[1999 Fed Cup Americas Zone Group I ‚Äì Pool A|Pool A]] | team-1-abbrev=ARG | team-1={{nowrap|{{fed|ARG}} (4‚Äì0)}} | team-2-abbrev=COL | team-2={{nowrap|{{fed|COL}} (3‚Äì1)}} | team-3-abbrev=PAR | team-3={{nowrap|{{fed|PAR}} (2‚Äì2)}} | team-4-abbrev=MEX | team-4={{fed|MEX}} (1‚Äì3) | team-5-abbrev=ECU | team-5={{fed|ECU}} (0‚Äì4) | 1v2=3‚Äì0 |1v3=3‚Äì0 |1v4=3‚Äì0 |1v5=3‚Äì0 |2v1=0‚Äì3 | 2v3=3‚Äì0 |2v4=3‚Äì0 |2v5=3‚Äì0 |3v1=0‚Äì3 |3v2=0‚Äì3 | 3v4=2‚Äì1 |3v5=2‚Äì1 |4v1=0‚Äì3 |4v2=0‚Äì3 |4v3=1‚Äì2 | 4v5=2‚Äì1 |5v1=0‚Äì3 |5v2=0‚Äì3 |5v3=1‚Äì2 |5v4=1‚Äì2 }} {{col-float-break|width=35em}} {{5TeamRR | title=[[1999 Fed Cup Americas Zone Group I ‚Äì Pool B|Pool B]] | team-1-abbrev=VEN | team-1={{fed|VEN|1930}} (4‚Äì0) | team-2-abbrev=CAN | team-2={{fed|CAN}} (3‚Äì1) | team-3-abbrev=BRA | team-3={{fed|BRA}} (2‚Äì2) | team-4-abbrev=CHI | team-4={{fed|CHI}} (1‚Äì3) | team-5-abbrev=PUR | team-5={{nowrap|{{fed|PUR}} (0‚Äì4)}} | 1v2=2‚Äì1 |1v3=3‚Äì0 |1v4=2‚Äì1 |1v5=3‚Äì0 |2v1=1‚Äì2 | 2v3=2‚Äì1 |2v4=3‚Äì0 |2v5=3‚Äì0 |3v1=0‚Äì3 |3v2=1‚Äì2 | 3v4=2‚Äì1 |3v5=3‚Äì0 |4v1=1‚Äì2 |4v2=0‚Äì3 |4v3=1‚Äì2 | 4v5=3‚Äì0 |5v1=0‚Äì3 |5v2=0‚Äì3 |5v3=0‚Äì3 |5v4=0‚Äì3 }} {{col-float-end}}
===Play-off=== {{FedCupbox3 |team1=Argentina |team2=Venezuela |team2-var=1930 |venue=Buenos Aires T.C., [[Buenos Aires]], Argentina |date=18 April 1999 |surface=Clay (outdoors) |score1=3 |score2=0 |R1={{ TennisMatch3 |T1P1=[[Mariana D√≠az Oliva]] |6 |6 | |T2P1=[[Milagros Sequera]] |0 |3 | }} |R2={{ TennisMatch3 |T1P1=[[Paola Su√°rez]] |7 |3 |6 |T2P1=[[Mar√≠a Vento-Kabchi|Mar√≠a Vento]] |5 |6 |2 }} |R3={{ TennisMatch3 |T1P1=[[In√©s Gorrochategui]] |T1P2=[[Patricia Tarabini]] |7 |6 | |T2P1=[[Milagros Sequera]] |T2P2=[[Mar√≠a Vento-Kabchi|Mar√≠a Vento]] |6.045 |1 | }} |}} <ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.fedcup.com/en/results/tie/details.aspx?tieId=20004475|title=Argentina v Venezuela|publisher=fedcup.com}}</ref> * '''{{fed|ARG}}''' advanced to World Group II Play-offs.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.fedcup.com/en/results/tie/details.aspx?tieId=20005833|title=Australia v Argentina|publisher=fedcup.com}}</ref> * ''{{fed|ECU}}'' and ''{{fed|PUR}}'' relegated to Group II in 2000.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.fedcup.com/en/results/tie/details.aspx?tieId=20004651|title=Ecuador v Bahamas|publisher=fedcup.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.fedcup.com/en/results/tie/details.aspx?tieId=20003806|title=Puerto v Rico v Bermuda|publisher=fedcup.com}}</ref>
==Group II== *Venue: [[Costa Rica Country Club]], [[San Jos√©, Costa Rica|San Jos√©]], [[Costa Rica]] (outdoor hard) *Date: 23‚Äì27 February
The sixteen teams were randomly divided into four pools of four teams to compete in round-robin competitions. The top teams of each pool play-off in a two-round knockout stage with the two winners advancing to Group I for 2000.

{{Infobox football club | clubname = African Lyon FC | image = African Lyon Old PNG.png | caption = | fullname = African Lyon Football Club | nickname = | shortname = | founded = 14 June 2000 | formernames = Mbagara Market F.C. | dissolved = | ground = [[Karume Memorial Stadium]]
[[Dar es Salaam]], [[Tanzania]] | capacity = 5,000 | owntitle = Owner | owner = Rahim J Kangezi | chrtitle = Vice Chairman | chairman = Omar Al Raisi | mgrtitle = Head Coach | manager = Adam | league = [[Tanzanian Premier League]] | season = 2016/17 | position = 9th | website = http://www.africanlyonfc.com | kit_alt1 = | pattern_la1 = | pattern_b1 = | pattern_ra1 = | pattern_sh1 = | pattern_so1 = | leftarm1 = FF9933 | body1 = FF9933 | rightarm1 = FF9933 | shorts1 = 000000 | socks1 = FF9933 | kit_alt2 = | pattern_la2 = | pattern_b2 = | pattern_ra2 = | pattern_sh2 = | pattern_so2 = | leftarm2 = | body2 = | rightarm2 = | shorts2 = | socks2 = | kit_alt3 = | pattern_la3 = | pattern_b3 = | pattern_ra3 = | pattern_sh3 = | pattern_so3 = | pattern_name3 = | leftarm3 = | body3 = | rightarm3 = | shorts3 = | socks3 = | firstgame = | largestwin = | topscorer = | fansgroup = | honours = | American = | Vice Chairman = Omar Al Raisi }} '''African Lyon''' is a [[Football (soccer)|football]] club in [[Dar es Salaam]], [[Tanzania]]. Currently they play in the top level of Tanzanian professional football, the [[Tanzanian Premier League]], after winning the First Division League's Group A in the 2015/2016 season.{{cite web|title=TFF pays tribute to Lyon and Ruvu Shooting|url=http://www.thecitizen.co.tz/News/Sports/TFF-pays-tribute-to-Lyon-and-Ruvu-Shooting/-/1840572/3078826/-/wyx3mjz/-/index.html|website=The Citizen|accessdate=11 March 2016}} The club is owned by Rahim J Kangezi. In 2017 a minority stake of the club was purchased by Middle East-based sports media group, DANTANI, Inc. Sports¬Æ under the banner of Dantani Football Group¬Æ led by Omar Al Raisi. DANTANI, Inc. Sports¬Æ is a leading sports media group of companies that offers its partners a complete customizable range of services and a portfolio of sports rights. With offices in Abu Dhabi, Dar es Salaam, Bangkok, Singapore and Rio de Janeiro, DANTANI, Inc. Sports¬Æ group of companies include: Dantani Football Group¬Æ, The Sports Journal¬Æ, Sponsorlytix¬Æ, Dantani Sports Network¬Æ, Dantani Newswires¬Æ, Dantani TV Rights¬Æ and Arcosoft¬Æ. ==History== Founded on June 14, 2000, African Lyon FC is one of the top Football clubs in Tanzania, based in the capital city of Dar es Salaam. African Lyon plays in the top division of Tanzanian professional football league, the Tanzanian Premier League. The club is owned by Rahim Kangezi. In 2017 a minority stake of the club was purchased by Middle East-based sports media group, DANTANI, Inc. Sports under the banner of Dantani Football Group led by Omar Al Raisi. [[File:Dantani,_Inc._Sports.png|thumb|Dantani, Inc. Sports official logo]] [[File:Dantani Football Group.png|thumb|Dantani Football Group]] African Lyon FC has a three-part Mission: * To be one of the best sports franchises in East Africa * To help grow the sport of football in Tanzania * To establish a soccer academy where talented players can be nurtured and trained. African Lyon will only be positioned to achieve the second and third parts when we are successful with the first. We are taking this opportunity to launch our four-year strategic plan, Vision 2018. It is about connectivity, integration of teams and programs under a true club philosophy, sustainability for the future, and setting up strategic partnership with key international soccer franchises. The 2018 timeline is driven by several external factors: * '''''Preparation''''': increase in training hours * '''''Momentum''''': expansion plans targeted at the 2016 season * '''''Legacy Planning''''': strategic enrolment in national and international tournaments * '''''Opportunity''''': Emerging new talent from all over East Africa * '''''International Soccer scene:''''' Forming strategic partnerships with international brands Goals for success by the completion of Vision 2016 include: * Economic sustainability of all major lines of business, with net revenues redirected to African Lyon Foundation for investment into Club programs and other community initiatives * 75% fan loyalty as measured by a combination of on-going surveys and ticket renewal rates * Completed construction of new facilities throughout the Lower Mainland including National Training Centre; and two Community Fields * Introduction of African Lyon Community radio * 90% year over year employee retention On the way to reaching these goals, some key milestones that the Club is actively pursuing include: * Grow awareness of African Lyon brand by 10% * Develop and implement phase I of ‚ÄúAFRICAN LYON FC YOUTH ACADEMY‚Äù training programs for staff, volunteers, and vendors * Continuing to build youth programming through affiliations and regional partnerships * Increase club following by 40% '''''Creating opportunities''''' In our efforts to develop Tanzanian talent, in cooperation with our parent company have successfully facilitated a few Young Players who have demonstrated immense talent and determination to seek opportunities abroad. Amongst the players we have sent abroad are: # Nizar Khalfan (Signed 3 yr MLS, contract ‚Äì USA) # Nadir Canavaro (6 month extensive training with professional team ‚ÄìCanada) # Razak Khalfan (6 month ‚Äìaway season between Seattle Saunders and Vancouver Whitecaps-USA and Canada) # Zahoro Pazi (3 month trial period ‚ÄìGermany) # Hamis Thabit ( 1-month trial ‚ÄìUSA) # Mrisho Ngassa (Part of the Seattle Saunders squad against Manchester United ‚ÄìUSA) # Mbwana Samata ( African-Inter club player of the year (Based in Africa), CAF's Africas finest XI) We are continuously looking to create more opportunities for deserving young Tanzanian players to make their mark on the international scale. Also, in attempts to promote Tanzania as a developing sports hub, we have extended invitations to foreign teams to come participate in friendly matches against local teams. Among the international teams that have visited at or request include: # Seattle Saunders (USA) # Vancouver Whitecaps (Canada) # Clube Atletico Parranease (Brazil) '''''Football business seminars:''''' African Lyon FC has organized several football business seminars in Tanzania for the purpose of developing sports sector in the country, such seminars were: * PMI(Playbook Management International ) FOOTBALL BUSINESS SEMINAR ‚Äì 2012 About Playbook Management International (‚ÄúPMI‚Äù): PMI is a Dallas, Texas-based Sports Management Company that works with professional sports teams, venues and events all over the world to assist our partners in running a more efficient and profitable business operation. PMI brings over 50 years of professional sports management experience to our hand selected clients. For more information on PMI, please visit www.playbookmanagement.com * SEATTLE SOUNDERS‚ÄôS About the seminarCREATING, GROWING AND SUSTAINING YOUR FAN BASE ‚Äì MARKETING STRATEGIESWORKSHOP SEMINAR ‚Äì 2013 African Lyon in partnership with Seattle Sounders FC, a major league soccer (MLS) team in the United States was proud to host a workshop that would focus on the various marketing strategies that have been successfully implemented in building, growing and sustaining a fan base. The guest speaker was Mr. Kevin Griffin, the Director of Fan Development at SeattleSounders FC and head of delegation to Tanzania. Seattle Sounders FC is one of the most successful franchises in the history of U.S sports. Taking into account the very strong presence of other sports in the U.S (American Football, Basketball and Baseball) the success of Seattle Sounders is remarkable and we were very grateful that they accepted our invite to run this seminar here in Tanzania. '''''SPORTS PROGRAMS FOR GOVERNMENT OFFICIALS:''''' * USPORT In November 2008, African Lyon FV was able to organize some government officials ( Hon. Shamuhuna & Hon. Bendera) Sports delegation to depart to Indianapolis- USA to attend USport program for youth development. * SEATTLE SOUNDERS ‚Äì 2012 Organized and sent ho. Ezekiel Maige to Seattle sounders/Seahawks * SOCCERREX SEMINAR ‚Äì 2013 Organized and sent Ho. Amos Makala Deputy Minister for Sports * MEETING WITH PAUL ALLEN ‚Äì 2013 Organized a meeting between Minister of Tourism hon. Hamis Kagasheki and Microsoft Bing co-founder & Portland Trailblazers owner Mr. Paul Allen. * SOCCERREX SEMINAR ‚Äì 2014 I organized and sent hon. Fenela Mukandala, Minister of sports and youths. '''Status Report -Business with Seattle Sounders''' As stated above, I write to update you on the various business ventures with Seattle. Ifelt it is important to provide you with a report from my perspective so you could blend your intervention into the reluctance of this matter. # Paul Allen Stephen Hall, the managing director of Vulcan Capital, Paul Allen's private investment firm, came to Dar es Salaam on November 9‚Äì11 to discuss various project proposals. The main project that he discussed was the potential for ‚Äòmicro-grid solar in village or per-urban environments‚Äô in Tanzania. I set up several meetings on this. More about Vulcan Capital can be found here ‚Äìhttp://capital.vulcan.com/AboutVulcanCapital/Index.html # Microsoft Bing( Paul Allen is a co-founder of Microsoft Bing) # Portland Trailblazers(Owned by Paul Allen) The executives of this franchise NBA basketball team also made a presentation that was attended by Mr. Musa and I with TTB team. The presentation showed how we could extend the Seattle Agreement into Basketball so TTB can have visibility in Basketball, Football and Soccer. The only remaining sport on that North West Pacific area is Baseball. Paul Allen owns the baseball field next to the Seattle Stadium. # ‚ÄúThe Price is Right‚Äù Seattle also made headways in generating interest from producers of a TV show entitled ‚ÄúThe Price is Right‚Äù. You can find out more of the show here ‚Äì http://www.priceisright.com/ # Evening Magazine Seattle has presented an opportunity for TTB to film a week of episodes for the show, ''Evening Magazine'', featuring Tanzania as a premier tourism destination and highlighting the Sounders partnership with Tanzania. The project was approved and Seattle invested 60,000 USD on it, this was to be done every year but due to lack of cooperation from TTB it happened only once. # Micro grid Solar in Villages From various successful meetings between Stephen Hall, the Managing director of Vulcan Capital, Paul Allen's private Investment team with officers from REA and Minister of Energy, they were able to Invest 6 Million USD, for more information on this please check :http://offgrid-electric.com/) # Tanzania Effect on the Super bowl As it turns out the partnership between TTB and Seattle came to be known as the ‚Äòwinning Magic‚Äô by Seattle sounders and Hawks fans because since the advert appeared in late July 2012, Seattle's home teams became Undefeated at CenturyLink Field. # Joe Ricketts in Tanzania From a good built relationship with Seattle Sounders I was able to connect Tanzania with WealthiestInvestor Joe Ricketts who introduced learning through tablets computers to Tanzania mainland and Zanzibar schools that honored country's commitment to using technology to magnify educational impacts. Please see; http://www.joericketts.com/ '''IMG COLLEGE''' Organized a meeting between IMG College http://www.imgcollege.com/ and Hon. Jakaya Kikwete, President of Tanzania. The aim is to promote Youths and providing free scholarship to athlete kids from Tanzania to United States. ''About IMG:'' IMG College is the nation's leading collegiate sports marketing company, offering national, regional, and local multi-platform marketing opportunities targeting 190 million college sports fans ‚Äì the largest and most attractive sports fan base. IMG College is blazing new trails in the growing collegiate market with exclusive rights to nearly 90 universities and conferences in 51 of the top 56 Nielsen markets. IMG's exclusive rights include intellectual property, experiential and promotional assets, event signage, digital, tickets, hospitality, live event radio, and shoulder programming including coaches‚Äô TV and radio shows...customized for sponsors by a staff of nearly 400 sales and marketing professionals. IMG College, through its licensing affiliate, The Collegiate Licensing Company (CLC), also represents the exclusive trademark licensing and consumer product rights for nearly 200 top schools, conferences and bowl games, and provides a comprehensive suite of solutions-based services to schools in ticketing; stadium seating; fundraising; premium events and hospitality. IMG College produces 35,000 hours of radio programming annually on the largest network in the country, manages 5,000 hours of TV programming produced annually, is the leading publisher of college sports publications, and averages nearly 19 million unique visitors per month across its collegiate digital platforms. Headquartered in Winston-Salem, N.C., IMG College employs more than 700 people in nearly 100 offices throughout the U.S. It is my hopes someday become the premier soccer franchise in all of East Africa. We want to have the best facilities, best players, and most championships and be the team that our fans and our community are most proud of. We will continue to unroll Vision 2018 and look forward to reporting on the achievement of milestone goals as they occur. ==Current squad== {{Fs start}} {{Fs player|no=1|nat=Tanzania|name=[[Hamadi Waziri]]|pos=GK}} {{Fs player|no=2|nat=Tanzania|name=[[Bakari Omari]]|pos=DF}} {{Fs player|no=3|nat=Tanzania|name=[[Aziz Sibo]]|pos=DF}} {{Fs player|no=4|nat=Tanzania|name=[[Abou Ubwa]]|pos=DF}} {{Fs player|no=5|nat=Tanzania|name=[[Yahya Issa]]|pos=DF}} {{Fs player|no=6|nat=Tanzania|name=[[Godfrey Kumba]]|pos=DF}} {{Fs player|no=7|nat=Tanzania|name=[[Mohammed Baggio Abdallah]]|pos=MF|other=[[Captain (association football)|Captain]]}} {{Fs player|no=8|nat=Tanzania|name=[[Castory Mumbara]]|pos=MF}} {{Fs player|no=9|nat=Tanzania|name=[[Yusuf Abbas Soka]]|pos=FW}} {{Infobox film | name = Big Leaguer | image = BigLeaguer53.jpg | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[Robert Aldrich]] | producer = [[Matthew Rapf]] | writer = [[Herbert Baker (screenwriter)|Herbert Baker]] |basedon = story by Lou Morheim
[[John McNulty (journalist)|John McNulty]] | starring = [[Edward G. Robinson]]
[[Vera-Ellen]]
[[Jeff Richards (baseball player/actor)|Jeff Richards]]
[[Richard Jaeckel]]
[[William Campbell (film actor)|William Campbell]] | music = [[Alberto Colombo (composer)|Alberto Colombo]] | editing = [[Ben Lewis (film editor)|Ben Lewis]] | cinematography = [[William C. Mellor]] | studio = Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer | released = {{Film date|1953|08|19}} | runtime = 71 minutes | country = United States | language = English | budget = $498,000{{Citation | title = The Eddie Mannix Ledger | publisher = Margaret Herrick Library, Center for Motion Picture Study | place = Los Angeles}}.The figure has also been given as $800,000 - see Alain Silver and James Ursini, ''Whatever Happened to Robert Aldrich?'', Limelight, 1995 p 230 |gross = $559,000 }} '''''Big Leaguer''''' is a 1953 American [[sports film|sports]] [[drama (film and television)|drama film]] starring [[Edward G. Robinson]] and was the first film directed by [[Robert Aldrich]]. Although this story is fiction, Robinson's character in it, [[Hans Lobert]], was an actual baseball player who played for five [[Major League Baseball]] teams and managed the [[Philadelphia Phillies]]. Third-billed in the cast, [[Jeff Richards (baseball player/actor)|Jeff Richards]] was a professional ballplayer before he became an actor, and [[National Baseball Hall of Fame|Hall of Fame]] pitcher [[Carl Hubbell]] appears as himself. "It was not a personal film of my status at the time," said Aldrich later. "I feel the film was good but not indicative of what I wanted to express in the motion picture medium."{{cite book|page=12|title=Robert Aldrich : interviews|first=Robert|last=Aldrich|date=2004|publisher=University Press of Mississippi}} == Plot == John "Hans" Lobert runs a training camp in Florida for baseball's [[New York Giants]]. Every year, he evaluates the 18 to- 22-year-old hopefuls to pick the best for a minor league contract. All have dreams and talent, but the elimination whittles them down to a lucky few who will get the $150-a-month contract. Lobert's niece comes down from the home office in New York and finds herself attracted to one of the players, the tall, quiet Adam Polachuk. Polachuk, the best prospect at third base, is trying to earn a spot on the team without his father knowing about it. His father, who knows nothing about baseball, thinks Adam is attending school. His father finds out about Adam's attempt to make the Giants just before the best of the recruits square off against the Brooklyn Dodgers' rookie squad. The elder Polachuk is persuaded by manager Lobert to let his son play in the game before taking him home. Polachuk is the star of the game for the Giants both offensively and defensively as the Giants rally to win the game. == Cast == *[[Edward G. Robinson]] ... John B. 'Hans' Lobert *[[Vera-Ellen]] ... Christy *[[Jeff Richards (baseball player/actor)|Jeff Richards]] ... Adam Polachuk *[[Richard Jaeckel]] ... Bobby Bronson *[[William Campbell (film actor)|William Campbell]] ... Julie Davis *[[Carl Hubbell]] ... Himself *[[Paul Langton]] ... Brian McLennan *[[Lalo Rios]] ... Chuy Aguilar *Bill Crandall ... Tippy Mitchell *[[Frank Ferguson]] ... Wally Mitchell *John McKee ... Dale Alexander *[[Mario Siletti]] ... Mr. Polachuk *[[Al Campanis]] ... Himself *[[Bob Trocolor]] ... Himself *Tony Ravis ... Himself *Robert Calwell ... Pomfret *Donald 'Chippie' Hastings ... Little Joe Polachuk *[[Bing Russell]] *Harv Tomter ... Himself (uncredited) ==Production== The film was one of a series of low budget films made at MGM. According to Robert Aldrich, [[Louis B. Mayer]] "had wanted to put the sons of the guys who helped him form Metro into production work; and they had this thing called the sons of the pioneers... Three or four guys whose fathers had been helpful in first forming Metro." Mayer left MGM in 1951 but [[Dore Schary]] kept alive the idea, in part because of the success of a low budget unit at MGM which he ran in the early 1940s. In January 1952 he announced the formation of a new production unit under the supervision of [[Charles Schnee]]. It included several sons of executives who had helped establish MGM, Matthew Raft (son of [[Harry Rapf]]), Arthur Loew (son of [[Marcus Loew]]), and Sidney Franklin Jnr (son of [[Sidney Franklin (director)|Sidney Franklin]]). Other producers were Hayes Goetz, Henry Berman (brother of [[Pandro S. Berman]]) and Sol Fielding. The idea was to make ten to fifteen films a year.Fairbanks Will Make Episode Film; Schary Boosts Young Producers Schallert, Edwin. Los Angeles Times (1923-1995); Los Angeles, Calif. [Los Angeles, Calif]30 Jan 1952: A7. mr. film noir stays at the table Silver, Alain. Film Comment; New York Vol. 8, Iss. 1, (Spring 1972): 14-23. ''Big Leaguer'' was based on an original story by John McNulty, who sold it to producer Matthew Rapf at [[MGM]]. Herbert Butler wrote a script and in November 1952 MGM announced they would make the film under the [[Charles Schnee]] unit. Robinson signed later that month, the first film he had shot at MGM since ''Our Vines Have Tender Grapes''.JUDGE DISMISSES ACTION BY JARRICO: Rules R. K. O., Hughes Acted Within Rights in Removing Movie Credits From Writer By THOMAS M. PRYORS New York Times27 Nov 1952: 49. Filming would not begin until March 1953 to take advantage of spring training.'Julius Caesar' Will Miss Next Oscar Derby; 'Big Leaguer' Readying Schallert, Edwin. Los Angeles Times 27 Nov 1952: B11. Robert Aldrich had worked at Enterprise Studios as an assistant director and met Herbert Baker on ''[[So This is New York]]''. Baker recommended Aldrich as director because he had worked in television and "knew athletes". "They were looking for "bright young guys" who'd been on the firing line for a while, someone they thought they could give an opportunity to and who knew what he was doing because they didn't," said Aldrich. Aldrich was signed to direct in January 1953.'Andersen' Sets Record Los Angeles Times 7 Jan 1953: B7. Jeff Richards, who was cast a baseball player, had been a baseball player in real life.Looking at Hollywood: Baseball Movie Will Co-Star Jeff Richards and Hubbell Hopper, Hedda. Chicago Daily Tribune 15 Jan 1953: b2. Spring training filming took place at [[Melbourne, Florida]] with the real life [[New York Giants]]. The film was shot in [[Cape Kennedy]] in 17 days "out of nowhere" said Aldrich. Aldrich remembered star Edward G. Robinson as "a marvellous actor and a brilliant man but he was not physically co ordinated. He would walk to first base and trip over the home plate."{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HTGSCgAAQBAJ&pg=PA44&lpg=PA44&dq=%22edward+g+robinson%22+%22big+leaguer%22&source=bl&ots=sZBg_RIODW&sig=V-xWEjChynXjesuOxJVrhoIOuug&hl=en&sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwjAjKrQ79DeAhVFhlQKHWIgAjs4HhDoATABegQIBBAB#v=onepage&q=%22edward%20g%20robinson%22%20%22big%20leaguer%22&f=false|page=44|title=The Edward G. Robinson Encyclopedia|first=Robert|last=Beck|publisher=McFarlanddate=2008}} ==Reception== Aldrich said "The world wasn't waiting for that picture. It was a picture about the New York Giants and Metro had the foresight to open it in Brooklyn, so you can't have expected it to do very well. Nothing much came out of it." According to MGM records the film earned $467,000 in the US and Canada and $92,000 elsewhere, resulting in a loss of $163,000. ==References== {{reflist}} == External links == * {{IMDb title|0045556|Big Leaguer}} * {{Amg movie|85013|Big Leaguer}} {{Robert Aldrich}} [[Category:1953 films]] [[Category:1950s drama films]] [[Category:1950s sports films]] [[Category:American baseball films]] [[Category:American black-and-white films]] [[Category:American drama films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:Directorial debut films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Films directed by Robert Aldrich]] [[Category:Films set in Florida]] [[Category:Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer films]] [[Category:New York Giants (NL)]] {{1950s-drama-film-stub}} {{sport-film-stub}}

Aztec Stadium | nickname = ''El Coloso de Santa √örsula''
"The Colossus of Santa √örsula" | logo_image = [[File:Logotipo Estadio Azteca.png|200px]] | image = Estadio Azteca1706p2.jpg | caption = Stadium's exterior{{maplink|frame=yes|plain=yes|type=shape|zoom=15|frame-align=center|frame-width=220}} | location = [[Tlalpan]], [[Mexico City]] | coordinates = | broke_ground = 1961 | opened = 29 May 1966 | renovated = 1986, 1999, 2013 and 2016{{cite web|url=http://www.estadioazteca.com.mx/estadio/historia |title=Historia #5 |publisher=stadiumdb.com |accessdate=20 March 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160325031415/http://www.estadioazteca.com.mx/estadio/historia |archivedate=25 March 2016 |df=dmy }} | expanded = | owner = [[Grupo Televisa]] | operator = [[Club Am√©rica]] | surface = [[PlayMaster Hybrid Grass]] by Tarkett Sports | architect = [[Pedro Ram√≠rez V√°zquez]] | record_attendance = '''Football''': {{formatnum: 119853}} ([[Mexico national football team|Mexico]] vs [[Brazil national football team|Brazil]], 7 July 1968){{cite web |url=http://telefenoticias.com.ar/es/news/deportes/20130412/monumental-gana-bombonera-como-estadio-mas-emblematico/17518.shtml |title=El Monumental le gana a la Bombonera como estadio m√°s emblem√°tico |date=12 April 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130627161234/http://telefenoticias.com.ar/es/news/deportes/20130412/monumental-gana-bombonera-como-estadio-mas-emblematico/17518.shtml |archivedate=27 June 2013 |df=dmy-all }}
'''Boxing''': {{formatnum: 132247}} ([[Julio C√©sar Ch√°vez]] vs [[Greg Haugen]], 20 February 1993){{cite web |url=http://stadiumdb.com/stadiums/mex/estadio_azteca |title=StadiumDB: Estadio Azteca |accessdate=5 September 2013}} | dimensions = {{convert|105|x|68|m|abbr=on}} | tenants = [[Club Am√©rica]] (1966‚Äìpresent)
[[Cruz Azul]] (1971‚Äì1996, 2018‚Äìpresent)
[[Mexico national football team]] (1966‚Äìpresent)
[[Club Necaxa|Necaxa]] (1966‚Äì1971, 1982‚Äì2003)
[[Atlante F.C.|Atlante]] (1966‚Äì1982, 1996‚Äì2001, 2004‚Äì2007)
[[Club Universidad Nacional|UNAM]] (1967‚Äì1969)
[[Atl√©tico Espa√±ol]] (1971‚Äì1982) | publictransit = [[File:DFGGH.JPG|15px]] [[Xochimilco Light Rail]] | construction_cost = [[Mexican peso|MXN$]]260 million | former_names = | nicknames = | seating_capacity = 87,523{{cite web |url=http://resources.fifa.com/image/upload/united-2026-bid-book.pdf?cloudid=w3yjeu7dadt5erw26wmu |title=2026 FIFA World Cup Bid Book |format=PDF |page=161 |accessdate=5 April 2018}} | Suites = 856 }} The '''Estadio Azteca''' ({{IPA-es|esÀàta√∞jo asÀàteka}}) is an [[association football]] [[stadium]] located in the suburb of [[Santa √örsula, Mexico City|Santa √örsula]] in [[Mexico City]], and the home ground of [[Club Am√©rica]], [[Cruz Azul]], and the [[Mexico national football team]]. With an official capacity of 87,000,{{cite web|url=http://stadiumdb.com/news/2016/04/mexico_azteca_to_lose_capacity_again|title= Mexico: Azteca to lose capacity again|website=StadiumDB |date= 4 April 2016|accessdate=13 August 2016}} it is the largest stadium in Mexico. The stadium sits at an altitude of 7,200 feet (2195 meters) above sea level.{{cite web|last=Longman |first=Jer√© |date=10 August 2009 |title=In Mexico, a Soccer Stadium Where Visitors Gasp |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/08/11/sports/soccer/11soccer.html |work=The New York Times |quote=The massive bowl, Estadio Azteca, sits in the southern part of this sprawling metropolis like a concrete sombrero. The stadium‚Äôs mystique ‚Äî especially its 105,000 spectators and its 7,200-foot altitude ‚Äî will play an integral role Wednesday in a World Cup qualifying match between Mexico and the United States. |accessdate=22 April 2017}} As of 2018, the stadium also serves as the home ground for Cruz Azul.{{cite web|title=Mexico City: Cruz Azul to relocate to Azteca |url=http://stadiumdb.com/news/2017/04/mexico_city_cruz_azul_to_relocate_to_azteca |website=StadiumDB |accessdate= 23 April 2017}} Regarded as one of the most famous and iconic football stadiums in the world,{{cite web|title=Ranking the Top 10 Most Iconic Stadiums in World Football|url=http://www.bleacherreport.com/articles/1593822-ranking-the-top-10-most-iconic-stadiums-in-world-football/page/11|publisher=Bleacherreport|accessdate=5 April 2013}}{{cite web|title=Classic Stadium: Estadio Azteca|url=https://www.fifa.com/classicfootball/stadiums/stadium=5000118/|publisher=FIFA.com}}{{cite web|last=Smart|first=Tony|title=10 of the world's best sports venues|url=http://www.travel.cnn.com/explorations/play/worlds-ten-best-sports-venues-535572|publisher=CNN|accessdate= 9 March 2012}}{{cite web|last=Mazur|first=Martin|title=FourFourTwo‚Äôs 100 Best Football Stadiums in the World: No.4|url=https://www.fourfourtwo.com/features/fourfourtwos-100-best-football-stadiums-world-no4|publisher=FourFourTwo|accessdate=13 November 2015}}{{cite web|last=Gordon|first=Aaron|title=Mexico wins Mexican-American stadium war|url=https://www.buzzfeed.com/aarongordon/what-the-georgia-dome-could-learn-from-the-best-stadium-in-n?s|publisher=Buzzfeed|accessdate=9 April 2013}} it is the first to have hosted two [[FIFA World Cup]] Finals.{{cite web|title=Mexico's historical stadium|url=https://www.fifa.com/newscentre/features/news/newsid=1642064/index.html?intcmp=fifacom_hp_module_news|publisher=[[FIFA]].com|accessdate=31 May 2012}} In the [[1970 FIFA World Cup|1970 World Cup]] [[1970 FIFA World Cup Final|Final]], [[Brazil national football team|Brazil]] defeated [[Italy national football team|Italy]] 4‚Äì1, and in the [[1986 FIFA World Cup|1986 World Cup]] [[1986 FIFA World Cup Final|Final]], [[Argentina national football team|Argentina]] defeated [[West Germany national football team|West Germany]] 3‚Äì2. It also hosted [[Argentina v England (1986 FIFA World Cup)|the 1986 quarter-final match]] between Argentina and [[England national football team|England]] in which [[Diego Maradona]] scored both the "[[Argentina 2‚Äì1 England (1986 FIFA World Cup)#"Hand of God" goal|Hand of God goal]]" and the "[[Argentina 2‚Äì1 England (1986 FIFA World Cup)#The Goal of the Century|Goal of the Century]]". The stadium also hosted the "[[Game of the Century (football)|Game of the Century]]", when Italy defeated West Germany 4‚Äì3 in extra time in one of the 1970 semifinal matches. The stadium was also the principal venue for the [[Football at the 1968 Summer Olympics|football tournament]] of the [[1968 Summer Olympics]].[https://web.archive.org/web/20081118070058/http://www.la84foundation.org/6oic/OfficialReports/1968/1968v2pt1.pdf 1968 Summer Olympics official report.] Volume 2. Part 1. pp. 78‚Äì79. ==History== [[File:Estadio Azteca 07a.jpg|right|thumb|An internal view of the stadium]] The Estadio Azteca was designed by architects [[Pedro Ram√≠rez V√°zquez]] and [[Rafael Mijares Alc√©rreca]] and broke ground in 1961. The inaugural match was between [[Club Am√©rica]] and [[Torino F.C.]] on 29 May 1966, with a capacity for 107,494 spectators. The first goal was scored by Brazilian Arlindo Dos Santos and the second one by Brazilian [[Jos√© Alves "Zague"]]; later, the Italians tied the game, which ended in 2‚Äì2 draw. Mexican president [[Gustavo D√≠az Ordaz]] made the initial kick and [[FIFA]] president [[Sir Stanley Rous]] was the witness. A modern illumination system was inaugurated on June 5, 1966 with the first night game played between Spanish side [[Valencia C.F.]] and [[Club Necaxa|Necaxa]]. The first goal of the match was scored by [[Honduras|Honduran]] [[Jos√© Cardona]] for Valencia. Roberto Mart√≠nez, aka Ca√±a Brava, became the first Mexican to score a goal in the stadium after scoring for Necaxa. The result was a 3‚Äì1 victory for Valencia. In 1978 the stadium hosted the final of the [[Copa Interamericana]] between Am√©rica and [[Boca Juniors]] of [[Argentina]], and would host a final again in 1990 between Am√©rica and [[Club Olimpia]] of [[Paraguay]]. The Estadio Azteca is also the site in which [[Pel√©]] and [[Diego Maradona]] (during the [[1970 FIFA World Cup|1970]] and [[1986 FIFA World Cup]]) lifted the trophy for the last time (The [[FIFA World Cup Trophy#Jules Rimet Trophy|Jules Rimet Trophy]] and the current [[FIFA World Cup Trophy#FIFA World Cup Trophy|FIFA World Cup Trophy]], respectively). Estadio Azteca has also been used for musical performances throughout its history. [[Michael Jackson]] (5 sold-out shows in 1993),{{cite web|title=Cronolog√≠a Estadio Azteca|url=http://www.esmas.com/estadioazteca/quienes/|accessdate=13 September 2007|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070816080659/http://www.esmas.com/estadioazteca/quienes/|archivedate=16 August 2007|df=dmy-all}} [[U2]] (in 2006 and 2011), [[Luis Miguel]] (in 2002), [[Elton John]], [[Man√°]], [[Juan Gabriel]], [[Gloria Estefan]], [[Jaguares (band)|Jaguares]], [[Lenny Kravitz]], [[*Nsync]], [[Hanson (band)|Hanson]], [[Ana Gabriel]], and [[The Three Tenors]] all have become part of the stadium's main spectacle. The stadium has also been used for political events, including Mexican president [[Felipe Calder√≥n]]'s campaign closure in 2006, as well as religious events, such as Jehovah's Witnesses conventions, and the appearance of Pope [[John Paul II]] in 1999.{{cite web |title=Pide Juan Pablo II "superar" deficiencias en el progreso social|url=http://www.jornada.unam.mx/1999/01/26/llama.html|accessdate=12 October 2007}} In April 2017, it was announced that starting July 2018, [[Cruz Azul]] would relocate to the Azteca on a temporary basis, due to the impending demolition of the [[Estadio Azul]]. According to club owner Guillermo √Ålvarez, they plan on building a new private stadium, which could take an estimated three-to-four years. ===2015‚Äì19 renovation plans=== The stadium has undergone gradual improvements and renovations, including the replacing of seating within the stadium as well as the installation of electronic advertising boards. In May 2015, modern [[Panasonic]] LED panels were installed at the north and south ends of the stadium, replacing the phosphorous panels installed in 1998.{{cite web|title=Panasonic's LED Large Screen Displays Provide an All-New Fan Experience at Estadio Azteca in Mexico City |url=http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20150608005673/en/Panasonics-LED-Large-Screen-Displays-Provide-All-New |work=[[Business Wire]] |publisher=Business Wire: A Berkshire Hathaway Company |date=8 June 2015 |access-date=28 July 2016}} In February 2015, a vast renovation plan was unveiled with the intention that the completion of the project coincide with the stadium's 50th anniversary and with Club Am√©rica's [[centenary]] in 2016, as well as the construction of a commercial hub outside the stadium to be completed some time in 2019. It was reported that [[Grupo Televisa]], owners of the stadium, approved a joint-venture bid from private development firms IQ Real Estate and Alhel. The hub, named "Foro Azteca", will reportedly consist of a mall, office spaces, two hotels, new leisure spaces and parking spaces for 2,500 cars. The renovations to the stadium were planned in two phases; the first saw the demolition of the restaurant and seating at the lower east stand and the construction of a new hospitality area with dining and banqueting spaces. The second phase consisted of the construction of new media boxes and private skyboxes at the upper west stand.{{cite web|title=Mexico: Azteca to lose capacity again |url=http://stadiumdb.com/news/2016/04/mexico_azteca_to_lose_capacity_again |website=StadiumDB.com |date=4 April 2016 |access-date=28 July 2016}} The renovations to the stadium were completed in November 2016.{{cite web |title=El 'nuevo' Azteca |url=http://www.milenio.com/americano/estadio_azteca-nfl_mexico-oakland-raiders-houston-texans-milenio-la_aficion_0_839316453.html |trans-title=The 'new' Azteca |language=Spanish |work=La Afici√≥n |publisher=Grupo Milenio |accessdate=17 November 2016}} The seating capacity was ultimately reduced to 87,000 as a result of the renovations. ==Name== [[File:Estadio Azteca 07b.jpg|thumb|left|Estadio Azteca prior to a kickoff]] The name "Azteca" is a tribute to the [[Aztec]] heritage of Mexico City. The stadium is currently owned by Mexican multimedia conglomorate [[Televisa]], which has a heated media rivalry with the similarly-named [[TV Azteca]]. Although there had been little to no confusion between the stadium and television network (which had only come into existence four years before in 1993), Televisa officially changed the stadium's name to '''Estadio Guillermo Ca√±edo''' on January 20, 1997, in tribute to [[:es:Guillermo Ca√±edo de la B√°rcena|Guillermo Ca√±edo de la B√°rcena]], a top network executive, former [[Mexican Football Federation]] president, and a prominent member of the [[FIFA]] executive committee who had died that day.{{cite web|title=FIFA Senior Vice President Guillermo Ca√±edo has died|url=https://www.fifa.com/newscentre/news/newsid=70175/index.html|publisher=FIFA.com|accessdate=21 January 1997}} As with the similar situation with the defunct [[Candlestick Park]] in [[San Francisco]] in the United States and its sponsored names, few outside of Televisa itself took up the new name, and most of the general public probably had no thought about the stadium's ownership (much less the Televisa/Azteca rivalry) and continued to refer to the Estadio Azteca by its original (and current) name. After two of Ca√±edo's sons took a business interest in TV Azteca in 1998,{{cite web| last = Mart√≠nez| first = C√©sar| title = Ca√±edo Whites go to TV Azteca| url=http://www.jornada.unam.mx/1998/01/07/canedo.html| work=La Jornada| accessdate = 13 September 2007}} Televisa quietly returned to referring to it solely as Estadio Azteca. Known colloquially by the nickname "Coloso de Santa √örsula", which in English translates to "Colossus of Saint Ursula", due to its large structure and [[Santa √örsula, Mexico City|Santa √örsula]] referring to the suburb where the stadium is located.{{cite web|last=Rai|first=Asha|date=14 March 2014|title=Estadio Azteca: Seasons in the Sun|url=http://blogs.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/life-notes/entry/estadio-azteca-seasons-in-the-sun|work=[[The Times of India]]|accessdate=17 March 2014}} ==Access and entrance== It is served by the Azteca station on the [[Xochimilco Light Rail]] line. This line is an extension of the [[Mexico City metro]] system which begins at [[Metro Tasque√±a]] station and ends in the Xochimilco Light Rail Station. Tickets are available up until kick-off times from the ticket office which is located at the front of the stadium, located towards the exit ramps from the Azteca station. Prices start from as little as [[Mexican peso|MXN$]]100 (about US$5 as of 2016), and could cost up to MXN$500 (about US$26 as of 2016) for more high-profile matches.{{cite web|title=Estadio Azteca |url=http://www.stadiumguide.com/azteca/ |publisher=Stadium Guide}} {{Panorama |image = File:Panorama Estadio Azteca football game Club America.jpg | height = 230 | fullwidth = 2400 | fullheight = 473 | caption =
A [[panorama]] of Estadio Azteca during a Club Am√©rica match ([[Mexico City]]) vs [[UAG Tecos|Tecos]] ([[Guadalajara, Jalisco|Guadalajara]]),
}} ==Monuments and memorials== [[File:Game of the Century Plaque.jpg|thumb|right|Plaque commemorating the "[[Game of the Century (football)|Game of the Century]]"]] A [[Commemorative plaque|commemorative bronze plaque]] of the "[[Game of the Century (football)|Game of the Century]]" played between [[Italy national football team|Italy]] and [[Germany national football team|West Germany]], as well as [[Diego Maradona]]'s "[[Goal of the Century]]" against [[England national football team|England]]. There is also a commemorative plaque with the names of the first goal scorer in the inaugural match and in the first match played at night. ==Notable events== [[File:Estadio azteca.jpg|right|thumb|Spectators outside Estadio Azteca]] Estadio Azteca has hosted a variety of international sporting competitions, including: ===Association Football=== *[[Football at the 1968 Summer Olympics|1968 Summer Olympics]] *[[1970 FIFA World Cup]] *[[1975 Pan American Games]] *[[1983 FIFA World Youth Championship]] *[[1985 Azteca 2000 Tournament|1985 Mexico City Cup / Azteca 2000]] *[[1986 FIFA World Cup]] *[[1993 CONCACAF Gold Cup]] *[[1999 FIFA Confederations Cup]] *[[2003 CONCACAF Gold Cup]] *[[2011 FIFA U-17 World Cup]] *The 1971 final of the [[Martini (vermouth)|Martini]] supported and from FIFA independent "Ladies World Championships"{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vu9TBAAAQBAJ&pg=PA26&lpg=PA26&dq=Martini,+Ladies+World+Cup+1971&source=bl&ots=ndZwQuYU4a&sig=03_7rlgifrQWuu1fSW-Hj3piiIY&hl=sv&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjA5d__z9vUAhVhP5oKHSTmCScQ6AEINzAG#v=onepage&q=Martini,+Ladies+World+Cup+1971&f=false|title=Women, Soccer and Transnational Migration|first1=Sine|last1=Agergaard|first2=Nina Clara|last2=Tiesler|date=21 August 2014|publisher=Routledge|via=Google Books}}{{cite web|url=https://www.dr.dk/tv/se/da-danmark-blev-verdensmestre-i-fodbold/-/temaloerdag-da-danmark-blev-verdensmestre-i-fodbold|title=Da Danmark blev verdensmestre i fodbold - TV - DR|publisher=}} |1986-06-29||12:00||{{fb|West Germany}}||style="text-align:center;"|2-3||{{fb|ARG}}||[[1986 FIFA World Cup Final|Final]]||style="text-align:center;"|114,600 |} ===American football=== {{see also|American Bowl|F√∫tbol Americano|NFL International Series}} *On 15 August 1994, Estadio Azteca hosted a preseason [[American Bowl]] game between the [[1994 Houston Oilers season|Houston Oilers]] and [[1994 Dallas Cowboys season|Dallas Cowboys]] which still holds the record for the highest attendance at any [[National Football League|NFL]] game, with 112,376 in attendance.{{cite web|title=Cowboys set regular season attendance record |url=http://www.profootballhof.com/news/cowboys-set-regular-season-attendance-record/ |publisher=Pro Football Hall of Fame |date=August 21, 2009 |accessdate=July 14, 2016}} The Houston Oilers won the game 6–0. *On 2 October 2005, the first international regular-season game in the history of the NFL was played in the stadium between the [[2005 San Francisco 49ers season|San Francisco 49ers]] and the [[2005 Arizona Cardinals season|Arizona Cardinals]]. The game was a 31–14 victory for the Cardinals. It set the record of the largest crowd to attend a regular-season NFL game with 103,467, but this record would be broken in 2009. *On 21 November 2016, the [[2016 Oakland Raiders season|Oakland Raiders]] hosted a home game along with the [[2016 Houston Texans season|Houston Texans]] as part of the [[NFL International Series]] in the first game dubbed '''NFL Mexico Game'''. It was the first [[Monday Night Football]] game played outside the United States.{{cite web|title=Back to Mexico: Texans-Raiders to play Nov. 21 in Mexico City |url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story/0ap3000000632878/article/back-to-mexico-texansraiders-to-play-nov-21-in-mexico-city |publisher=NFL.com |date=February 5, 2016 |accessdate=February 6, 2016}} The game saw a sell-out crowd of 76,743 in a renovated Estadio Azteca.{{cite web|title=Oakland Raiders Rally Past Houston Texans in Mexico City | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/11/22/sports/football/oakland-raiders-houston-texans.html?_r=0 | publisher=''New York Times'' |date=November 22, 2016 |accessdate=November 22, 2016}} *On 19 November 2017, the [[2017 Oakland Raiders season|Raiders]] hosted the [[2017 New England Patriots season|Patriots]] at the stadium.Shook, Nick (2017-11-18). What to watch for in Patriots-Raiders in Mexico. NFL.com, 18 November 2017. Retrieved on 2017-11-19 from http://www.nfl.com/news/story/0ap3000000878710/article/what-to-watch-for-in-patriotsraiders-in-mexico. * The [[Kansas City Chiefs]] were scheduled to play the [[Los Angeles Rams]] at the stadium on 19 November 2018.{{cite web|title=Chiefs-Rams to play in Mexico City next season|url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story/0ap3000000912789/article/chiefsrams-to-play-in-mexico-city-next-season|website=NFL.com}} However, due to poor field conditions brought on by recent events, as well as rain, the NFL cancelled the event and moved it to the Rams' home stadium [[Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum]].{{Cite news|url=http://www.espn.com/nfl/story/_/id/25268527/nfl-cancels-mexico-city-trip-moves-chiefs-rams-game-la-monday-night-football|title=NFL moves Rams-Chiefs from Mexico City to L.A.|work=ESPN.com|access-date=2018-11-13|language=en}} {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:left; width:95%;" style="text-align:center" |- !style="text-align:center;|Date !style="text-align:center;|Away Team !style="text-align:center;|Result !style="text-align:center;|Home Team !style="text-align:center;|Attendance |- | August 15, 1994 || '''[[1994 Houston Oilers season|Houston Oilers]]''' || 6‚Äì0 || [[1994 Dallas Cowboys season|Dallas Cowboys]] || 112,376 |- | August 17, 1998 || '''[[1998 New England Patriots season|New England Patriots]]''' || 21‚Äì3 || [[1998 Dallas Cowboys season|Dallas Cowboys]] || - |- | August 19, 2000 || '''[[2000 Indianapolis Colts season|Indianapolis Colts]]''' || 24‚Äì23 || [[2000 Pittsburgh Steelers season|Pittsburgh Steelers]] || - |- | August 19, 2001 || [[2001 Oakland Raiders season|Oakland Raiders]] || 21‚Äì6 || '''[[2001 Dallas Cowboys season|Dallas Cowboys]]''' || - |- | October 2, 2005 || [[2005 San Francisco 49ers season|San Francisco 49ers]] || 14‚Äì31 || '''[[2005 Arizona Cardinals season|Arizona Cardinals]]''' || 103,467 |- | November 21, 2016 || [[2016 Houston Texans season|Houston Texans]] || 20‚Äì27 || '''[[2016 Oakland Raiders season|Oakland Raiders]]''' || 76,473 |- | November 19, 2017 || '''[[2017 New England Patriots season|New England Patriots]]''' || 33‚Äì8 || [[2017 Oakland Raiders season|Oakland Raiders]] || 77,357 |- | November 19, 2018 || [[2018 Kansas City Chiefs season|Kansas City Chiefs]] || N/A ||[[2018 Los Angeles Rams season|Los Angeles Rams]] || cancelled |} ===Concerts=== *On 12 March 1983, [[Menudo (band)|Menudo]] was the first band to sell out a solo concert at the stadium with an attendance of over 100,000 people.{{citation needed|date=July 2017}} *On 29, 31 October and 07, 09 and 11 November 1993, [[Michael Jackson]] finished the [[Dangerous World Tour]] with five sold out shows at this stadium, for a total of 500,000 people (circa 100,000 per show, more than any other artist or band, Mexican or International).{{citation needed|date=July 2017}} *On 14 and 15 February 1997, [[Gloria Estefan]] performed at the stadium. *On 16 June 2000, Los Temerarios performed at the Estadio Azteca for the first time in their career, in a sold out concert with the max of capacity, was over 87,000 people that attended. This concert was filmed in live.{{citation needed|date=July 2017}} *On 14 May 2011, Irish rock band [[U2]] presented the [[360¬∞ Tour]] scoring the most-attended concert on the tour with a total attendance of 110,000 people.{{citation needed|date=July 2017}} *On 8 May 2012, [[Paul McCartney]] performed at the Estadio Azteca for the first time in his career, in a non-sold-out concert for 53,000 people.https://www.webcitation.org/68PkwyNx5?url=http://www.billboard.biz/bbbiz/charts/currentboxscore.jsp *On 16 April 2016, [[Vicente Fern√°ndez]] played his farewell concert, titled "UN AZTECA EN EL AZTECA, ADI√ìS A UN GRANDE", to a sell out crowd at the stadium with an attendance of over 100,000 people.{{citation needed|date=July 2017}} *On 11 and 12 October 2018, [[Shakira]] performed for around 150,000 fans with her [[El Dorado World Tour]]. ===Christian events=== *Nigerian Pastor [[T.B. Joshua]] held a two-day Christian crusade, attracting an estimated 150,000 over both days.{{Cite news| first = Gerardo | last = Elorriaga | title = El azote del maligno | url = http://www.diariosur.es/sociedad/201506/02/azote-maligno-20150602202721.html | work = Diario Sur (Spain) | date = 2015-06-07}} *From December 13 to 14, 2013, assemblies were held by the Jehovah's Witnesses to commemorate their religious devotion with a series of performances in scenes of biblical passages, social-contemporary themes and Christian baptisms, of which each day record of participation of 105,000 faithful, of which on Sunday there was the record time of eviction of 10 minutes for reasons of other scheduled events and in turn 2000 participants were dedicated to cleaning after each event.{{Cite news|url=https://testigodejehova.wordpress.com/2013/12/15/estadio-azteca-rompe-marca-de-desalojo/|title=Estadio Azteca rompe marca de desalojo|date=2013-12-15|work=Testigos de Jehov√°-Jehovah's Witnesses|access-date=2018-04-05|language=es-ES}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.nacion.com/puro-deporte/otros-deportes/testigos-de-jehova-limpian-el-estadio/V4M7DLFZ75E55PXJB52CSWVKKI/story/|title=Testigos de Jehov√° limpian el Estadio|work=La Naci√≥n, Grupo Naci√≥n|access-date=2018-04-05|language=es-LA}} ===Funeral services=== *A public funeral service for popular Mexican comedian [[Chespirito|Roberto Gomez "Chespirito" Bola√±os]] was held at Azteca on 30 November 2014, and was attended by 40,000 spectators. Chespirito had been a long-time supporter of Club Am√©rica.{{Cite web|url=https://losandes.com.ar/article/-con-un-multitudinario-funeral-en-el-estadio-azteca-mexico-despidio-a-chespirito|title=Con un multitudinario funeral en el estadio Azteca, M√©xico despidi√≥ a Chespirito|website=losandes.com.ar|language=es-AR|access-date=2018-11-13}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.espn.com/soccer/name/22/blog/post/2170764/headline|title=Remembering Roberto G√≥mez Bola√±os|work=ESPN.com|access-date=2018-11-13|language=en}} ==See also== *[[List of football stadiums in Mexico]] ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==Further reading== * [http://fifaworldcup.yahoo.com/06/en/050110/1/2xdd.html "Magical memories live on in the vaunted Azteca"] ‚Äì fifaworldcup.com ‚Äì [[FIFA]] ==External links== {{commons category|Estadio Azteca}} * [https://www.estadioazteca.com.mx Official Site of the Estadio Azteca] {{coord|19|18|10.48|N|99|9|1.59|W|region:MX_type:landmark_scale:2000|display=title}} {{s-start-collapsible|header={{s-sta|et}}}} {{Succession box | before =[[National Olympic Stadium (Tokyo)|National Stadium]]

{{Infobox NCAA football single game |Name=FIU-Miami football brawl |Date=October 14, 2006 |Year=2006 |Home School=University of Miami |Home Name Short=Miami |Home Nickname=Hurricanes |Home Record=4‚Äì2 |Home AP = |Home Coaches = |Home Coach=[[Larry Coker]] |Visitor School=Florida International University |Visitor Name Short=FIU |Visitor Nickname=Golden Panthers |Visitor Record=0‚Äì7 |Visitor AP = |Visitor Coach=[[Don Strock]] |Visitor1=0 |Home1=0 |Visitor2=0 |Home2=7 |Visitor3=0 |Home3=14 |Visitor4=0 |Home4=14 |Visitor Total=0 |Home Total=35 |Type= |Stadium=[[Miami Orange Bowl]] |City=[[Miami|Miami, Florida]] |US Network = |US Announcers = }} The '''FIU‚ÄìMiami football brawl''' was a [[bench-clearing brawl]] that occurred on October 14, [[2006 NCAA Division I FBS football season|2006]] in a [[college football]] game between the [[2006 Miami Hurricanes football team|University of Miami Hurricanes]] and the [[2006 FIU Golden Panthers football team|Florida International University Golden Panthers]] (now Panthers) at the [[Miami Orange Bowl]] in [[Miami|Miami, Florida]]. ==Background== The main campuses of Florida International University (FIU) and the University of Miami are only nine miles (15 km) apart. FIU is a [[public university]] located in western Miami (playing at [[FIU Stadium]]), while the University of Miami is a [[private university]] in the suburb of [[Coral Gables, Florida|Coral Gables]] (which at the time played its home games at the [[Miami Orange Bowl]]). The 2006 game was intended to be the first in the "City Line Series," an annual series between the two Miami-area schools. Miami was heavily favored over FIU,{{cite web|url=http://www.covers.com/pageLoader/pageLoader.aspx?page=/data/ncf/teams/pastresults/2006-2007/team70.html|title=Covers.com Miami Hurricanes 2006‚Äì2007|accessdate=2010-12-29}} Miami was favored by 27. which was in its fifth season of football and in its second year in the [[NCAA Division I Football Bowl Subdivision|Division I FBS]]. ==The brawl== Throughout the game, players from both teams engaged in [[trash-talk]] and were increasingly physical. By the third quarter, officials had called seven penalties (six for FIU and one for Miami).[http://sports.espn.go.com/ncf/playbyplay?gameId=262872390&quarter=0 Miami-FIU Play-by-Play on ESPN] With 9 minutes left in the 3rd quarter, Miami [[H-back]] [[James Bryant (American football)|James Bryant]] caught a 5-yard [[touchdown]] pass from [[quarterback]] [[Kyle Wright]], making the score 13-0 Miami. After scoring, Bryant pointed towards Miami's West end zone. Bryant, who later transferred to the [[Louisville Cardinals football|University of Louisville]], was [[American football#Penalties|called]] for [[unsportsmanlike conduct]].{{cite web|author=Degnan, Susan Miller|title=Brawl mars UM-FIU game|url=http://www.miami.com/mld/miamiherald/15763312.htm|work=Miami Herald|date=October 15, 2006|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061104233132/http://www.miami.com/mld/miamiherald/15763312.htm|archivedate=November 4, 2006|accessdate=May 30, 2014}} During the ensuing [[Conversion (gridiron football)|PAT]] attempt, FIU safety [[Chris Smith (CFL player)|Chris Smith]] wrestled Miami holder Matt Perelli to the ground after the kick and appeared to punch him in the chin. FIU cornerback, Marshall McDuffie, Jr., kicked Perelli in the head.{{cite web|last=Reynolds|first=Tim|title=Fallout From Miami, FIU Reverberates|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/10/16/AR2006101600125.html|publisher=Associated Press|accessdate=May 31, 2014|date=October 16, 2006}} Miami players, including [[Calais Campbell]], came to Perelli's defense, separating Miami and FIU players. FIU's [[Lionell Singleton]] punched Campbell in the back of the helmet, which was quickly followed by retaliation from both teams, escalating the fight to a bench-clearing brawl. Miami's [[Anthony Reddick]] swung his helmet at FIU players and Miami's [[Brandon Meriweather]] kicked an FIU player. FIU's [[A'Mod Ned]], who was previously injured, came onto the field and swung at Miami players with his crutches. The fight lasted less than two minutes with [[Florida Highway Patrol]] State Troopers and FIU Police coming onto the field to restore order. Officials needed several minutes to sort out the penalties. Ultimately, 13 players were assessed 15-yard penalties for fighting and ejected from the game (eight from FIU and five from Miami).{{cite web|author=Costa, Brian|url=http://www.miami.com/mld/miamiherald/sports/colleges/fiu/15762949.htm|title=Thirteen players ejected after fight during UM-FIU game|work=Miami Herald|date=October 15, 2006|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061105000819/http://www.miami.com/mld/miamiherald/sports/colleges/fiu/15762949.htm|archivedate=November 5, 2006|accessdate=May 30, 2014}} Although the unsportsmanlike conduct penalties for fighting offset each other, Miami was forced to kick off from its own 10-yard line due to the original penalty against Bryant (penalized at half the distance to the goal). After the brawl while waiting for the game to resume the Miami team was seen huddled in a circle in the sidelines hopping up and down in what appeared to be a celebratory gesture. There were also several fights in the stands between UM and FIU fans which were stopped by local police. Former Miami [[wide receiver]] [[Lamar Thomas]], who was broadcasting the game for [[Comcast/Charter Sports Southeast|Comcast Sports Southeast]] (CSS), made several controversial comments during the scuffle, including:
‚ÄúNow, that‚Äôs what I‚Äôm talking about. You come into our house, you should get your behind kicked. You don‚Äôt come into the OB [Orange Bowl] playing that stuff. You‚Äôre across the ocean over there. You‚Äôre across the city. You can‚Äôt come over to our place talking noise like that. You‚Äôll get your butt beat. I was about to go down the elevator to get in that thing...I say, why don't we meet outside in the tunnel after the ball game and get it on some more? You don't come into the OB, baby. We've had a down couple of years but you don't come in here talking smack. Not in our house.‚Äù{{cite web|url=http://nbcsports.msnbc.com/id/15290690/|title=Ex-'Cane Thomas fired for remarks on TV|accessdate=2009-10-12}}
==Aftermath== The incident was instantly condemned by all sides. FIU head coach [[Don Strock]] said he was "embarrassed" for what happened, and said that he would impose sanctions even more severe than any imposed by the [[Sun Belt Conference]], the conference in which FIU played at the time. Miami head coach [[Larry Coker]] said he was "shocked and angered" by the brawl but made no promises of further sanctions.{{cite web|author1=Milian, Jorge |author2=Lisier, Jason|url=http://www.palmbeachpost.com/sports/content/sports/epaper/2006/10/15/z1bb_um_1015.html|title=Brawl mars UM's shutout|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061031055433/http://www.palmbeachpost.com/sports/content/sports/epaper/2006/10/15/z1bb_um_1015.html|archivedate=October 31, 2006 |accessdate=2007-05-21}} The next day, 31 players from both schools ‚Äî 18 from FIU, 13 from Miami ‚Äî were handed one-game suspensions by their schools and conferences.{{cite web|last=Milian|first=Jorge|title=Fight night fallout: Coker says he has control of program|url=http://www.palmbeachpost.com/sports/content/sports/epaper/2006/10/16/a1c_um_1016.html|work=Palm Beach Post|accessdate=May 31, 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061017013848/http://www.palmbeachpost.com/sports/content/sports/epaper/2006/10/16/a1c_um_1016.html|archivedate=October 17, 2006|date=October 16, 2006}} *For FIU: cornerback Marshall McDuffie, Jr., cornerback Chris Smith, offensive lineman Michael Alls, offensive linemen Chad Sales, [[linebacker]] Mannie Wellington, linebacker Michael Dominguez, linebacker Scott Bryant, defensive lineman Roland Clarke, [[fullback (American football)|fullback]] John Ellis, defensive back Cory Fleming, defensive lineman Reginald Jones, defensive back Robert Mitchell, linebacker Quentin Newman, defensive lineman Luis Pena, defensive end Jarvis Penerton, running back Julian Reams, defensive back Lionell Singleton, tight end Samuel Smith and wide receiver Chandler Williams *For Miami: cornerback Carlos Armour, [[offensive tackle]] Chris Barney, H-back James Bryant, offensive tackle Tyrone Byrd, [[tight end]] DajLeon Farr, wide receiver Ryan Hill, cornerback [[Bruce Johnson (American football)|Bruce Johnson]], [[running back]] Charlie Jones, safety [[Brandon Meriweather]], [[punter (football position)|punter]] Brian Monroe, offensive guard Derrick Morse, cornerback [[Randy Phillips (American football)|Randy Phillips]] and safety Anthony Reddick In both schools' cases, the suspensions were not staggered, which was unusual considering the number of players involved. The ejected players (Chris Smith, McDuffie, Singleton, Ellis, Williams, Wellington and Penerton for FIU; Morse, Barney, Jones, Armour, Johnson and Samuel Smith for Miami) already faced minimum one-game suspensions under [[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]] regulations for ejections. On Monday, Miami's coach suspended Bryant, Merriweather and Reddick indefinitely and announced that the other players would have to complete community service and sit out the next game, against [[Duke Blue Devils football|Duke]]. Miami, which already had a history of such incidents, enacted a "zero tolerance" policy for future incidents: any Hurricane involved in a fight will be suspended for the remainder of the season, and could face permanent banishment from the team. The same day, FIU kicked Chris Smith and McDuffie off the team (though they were allowed to keep their [[athletic scholarship|scholarships]]), and the remaining players were suspended from the team indefinitely. FIU also placed the suspended players on probation for the remainder of the year. In contrast, Miami president [[Donna Shalala]] announced that the other 12 UM players would not face additional suspensions.{{cite web|author=Reynolds, Tim|title=Miami Defends Disciplinary Action |url=http://hosted.ap.org/dynamic/stories/F/FBC_MIAMI_BRAWL_FALLOUT|publisher=Associated Press|date=October 19, 2006|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061019072723/http://hosted.ap.org/dynamic/stories/F/FBC_MIAMI_BRAWL_FALLOUT|archivedate=October 19, 2006}} ESPN.com's [[Gene Wojciechowski]] called Miami's one-game suspensions "a soothing caress and manicure", suggested that Coker should be fired, and called for Miami to wipe the game from its records.{{cite web|last=Wojciechowski|first=Gene|url=http://www.espn.com/espn/columns/story?id=2628365|title=Laughable suspensions aren't nearly enough|publisher=ESPN|archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20071202015014/http://sports.espn.go.com/espn/columns/story?id=2628365|archivedate=December 2, 2007|date=October 17, 2006|accessdate=November 22, 2018}} Lamar Thomas was fired by CSS, and the network edited out his comments when it rebroadcast the game on October 18. Later in the day, he told [[ESPN Radio]]'s [[Dan Patrick]] that he had gotten carried away in the moment.[http://sports.espn.go.com/ncf/news/story?id=2628184# Lamar Thomas interview by Dan Patrick on ESPN Radio] Coker also came under fire for some of his comments after the incident. "I think that it will affect the image of our program greatly, but in a positive way," he said. "I think that when they see the video and they see how it was handled they will be impressed with our players."{{cite web|author=Brown, Joel|title=Miami melee: Third quarter brawl overshadows 'Canes' shutout victory|url=http://www.cstv.com/sports/m-footbl/uwire/101706aae.html|work=The Hurricane|publisher=University of Miami|date=October 17, 2006|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070217074312/http://media.www.thehurricaneonline.com/media/storage/paper479/news/2006/10/17/Sports/Miami.Melee-2352490.shtml|archivedate=February 17, 2007|accessdate=May 31, 2014}} His handling of the incident contributed to speculation that he would not return in 2007, Shalala's vote of confidence notwithstanding.{{cite web|author=Bianchi, Mike |url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/2006-11-10/sports/BIANCHI10_2_1_university-of-miami-um-florida-state |title=To rebuild image, 'Thug U' needs new leadership |work=[[Orlando Sentinel]] |date=November 10, 2006 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061126123331/http://www.orlandosentinel.com/sports/columnists/orl-bianchi10_206nov10%2C0%2C4491214.column?coll=orl-sports-col |archivedate=November 26, 2006 |accessdate=May 31, 2014 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Coker was fired at the end of the season,{{cite web|author=Reynolds, Tim|title=Miami fires football coach Larry Coker |url=http://hosted.ap.org/dynamic/stories/F/FBC_MIAMI_COKER_FIRED?SITE=DCSAS&SECTION=HOME&TEMPLATE=DEFAULT|publisher=Associated Press|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061124211156/http://hosted.ap.org/dynamic/stories/F/FBC_MIAMI_COKER_FIRED?SITE=DCSAS&SECTION=HOME&TEMPLATE=DEFAULT|archivedate=November 24, 2006|date=November 24, 2006}} while Strock resigned at the end of the season.{{cite web|author=Pelegrin, Pete|title=FIU's season comes to winless conclusion|url=http://www.miami.com/mld/miamiherald/sports/colleges/fiu/16152209.htm|work=Miami Herald|date=December 3, 2006|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070212235652/http://www.miami.com/mld/miamiherald/sports/colleges/fiu/16152209.htm|archivedate=February 12, 2007}} FIU ended the 2006 season 0-12 and would lose 23 straight games up to their final game of the 2007 season, a victory over [[2007 North Texas Mean Green football team|North Texas]].https://www.sports-reference.com/cfb/schools/florida-international/2006-schedule.htmlhttps://www.sports-reference.com/cfb/schools/florida-international/2007-schedule.html FIU and Miami played the following season, on September 15, 2007, without incident on the field as Miami won 23-9.{{cite web|author=Associated Press|url=http://scores.espn.go.com/ncf/recap?gameId=272582390|title=Hurricanes hand FIU 15th straight defeat|work=espn.com|accessdate=May 31, 2014|date=September 15, 2007}} FIU was coached by [[Mario Cristobal]], who was previously Miami's offensive line coach. The two schools played each other in football on September 22, 2018, marking the first game between the two since 2007. The game was held in Hard Rock Stadium which serves as the home field for both the NFL's Miami Dolphins and the University of Miami Hurricanes. Miami won 31-17.{{cite web|author=Degnan, Susan Miller|url=https://www.miamiherald.com/sports/college/acc/university-of-miami/article218820650.html|title=N‚ÄôKosi Perry makes grand entrance by leading Miami Hurricanes to 31-17 victory over FIU|work=Miami Herald|accessdate=September 23, 2018|date=September 22, 2018}} ==See also== * [[Clemson‚ÄìSouth Carolina football brawl]], a similar bench-clearing incident in 2004 ==References== {{reflist}} {{FIU Golden Panthers football navbox}} {{Miami Hurricanes football navbox}} {{DEFAULTSORT:FIU-Miami football brawl}} [[Category:2006 Atlantic Coast Conference football season]] [[Category:2006 Sun Belt Conference football season]] [[Category:Brawls in team sports]] [[Category:College football controversies]] [[Category:FIU Panthers football]] [[Category:Miami Hurricanes football]] [[Category:2006 in sports in Florida]] [[Category:2000s in Miami]] [[Category:2006 controversies in the United States]] [[Category:Controversies in Florida]] [[Category:October 2006 sports events]]

{{Infobox stadium |stadium_name=Farrington Field |image=Farrington.jpg |image_size=240px |caption=Farrington Field in Fort Worth, Texas |location=1501 N. University Dr.
[[Fort Worth, Texas]] |coordinates={{coord|32.745743|-97.360218|type:landmark}} |built=1938-1939 |opened=November 3, 1939 |renovated=2010 |owner=[[Fort Worth Independent School District|Fort Worth ISD]] |surface=artificial |cost=$400,000 |architect=Preston M. Geren |general_contractor=General Construction Co., Fort Worth |seating_capacity=18,500 |record_attendance=24,836 (November 23, 1944 [[North Side High School (Fort Worth, Texas)|North Side H.S.]] vs. [[R. L. Paschal High School|Paschal H.S.]]) |dimensions= |acreage= |tenants=*Fort Worth public schools *[[Fort Worth Braves]] *[[Fort Worth Vaqueros FC]] }} [[File:FarringtonFieldEXTERIOR.JPG|thumb|Farrington Field Exterior]] [[File:FarringtonFieldSTANDS.JPG|thumb|Farrington Field Grandstand]] '''Farrington Field''' is an 18,500-capacity multi-use stadium located in [[Fort Worth, Texas]]. The stadium was completed in 1939 and was named in memory of E.S. Farrington, a long time superintendent of the [[Fort Worth Independent School District]]. The stadium is the 2nd largest in Fort Worth proper and is used mainly for [[american football|football]] and [[track & field]]. ==External links== * [http://www.texasbob.com/stadium/stadium.php?id=242 Information at Texas Bob - Football stadiums] * [http://www.fortwortharchitecture.com/cd/farrington.htm Background at Fort Worth Architecture] * [http://www.star-telegram.com/2010/08/25/2425361/farrington-field-lives-on-as-a.html Farrington Field lives on as a visionary's legacy] from [[Fort Worth Star-Telegram]] {{Fort Worth ISD Revised}} [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1939]] [[Category:Art Deco architecture in Texas]] [[Category:American football venues in the Dallas‚ÄìFort Worth metroplex]] [[Category:High school football venues in Texas]] [[Category:Sports venues in Fort Worth, Texas]] [[Category:1939 establishments in Texas]] [[Category:Fort Worth Independent School District]]

{{Infobox film | name = Good News | image = GoodNews2.JPG | image size = | alt = | caption = Poster for the 1947 film | director = [[Charles Walters]] | producer = [[Arthur Freed]] | based on = {{based on|''[[Good News (musical)|Good News]]''
1927 musical|[[Lew Brown]]
Laurence Schwab
Frank Mandel
[[Buddy G. DeSylva]]
[[Ray Henderson]]}} | screenplay = [[Betty Comden]]
[[Adolph Green]] | narrator = | starring = [[June Allyson]]
[[Peter Lawford]]
Patricia Marshall | music = [[Conrad Salinger]] | cinematography = [[Charles Schoenbaum]] | editing = [[Albert Akst]] | studio = [[Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer]] | distributor = [[Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer]] | released = {{Film date|1947|12|26}} | runtime = 93 min. | country = United States | language = [[English language|English]] | budget = $1,715,000{{Citation | title = The Eddie Mannix Ledger | publisher = Margaret Herrick Library, Center for Motion Picture Study | place = Los Angeles}}. | gross = $2,956,000 }} [[File:Good News 1947.jpg|thumb|[[June Allyson]] and [[Peter Lawford]] ]] '''''Good News''''' is a 1947 [[Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer]] [[musical film]] based on the 1927 [[Good News (musical)|stage production of the same name]]. It starred [[June Allyson]], [[Peter Lawford]], [[Mel Torm√©]], and [[Joan McCracken]]. The [[screenplay]] by [[Betty Comden]] and [[Adolph Green]] was directed by [[Charles Walters]] in [[Technicolor]]. Three additional songs were written for the film: "The French Lesson", "Pass That Peace Pipe", and "An Easier Way", the last of which was cut from the released film. ''Good News'' was the second adaptation of the stage musical, after the 1930 film ''[[Good News (1930 film)|Good News]]''. The 1947 film was a more sanitized version of the musical; the 1930 version included [[Pre-Code]] content, such as sexual innuendo and lewd suggestive humor. ==Plot== The film is set in 1927 at [[fiction]]al Tait College, where [[College football|football]] is all the rage. ("Tait Song"/"Good News") Tait's football star Tommy Marlowe ([[Peter Lawford]]) is a prime catch for the college girls. Tommy tells his friend and non-playing teammate Bobby Turner (McDonald) that the trick to attracting girls is to show no interest. ("Be a Ladies' Man") New student Pat McClellan (Marshall) resists his advances, cutting Tommy down to size at a party. ("Lucky in Love") Pat is interested in French, so Tommy enlists part-time school [[librarian]] Connie Lane ([[June Allyson]]) to help him study the language. ("The French Lesson") He gradually falls for Connie, who comes from a poor background, which does not bother her. ("The Best Things in Life are Free") Meanwhile, Babe Doolittle (McCracken) is seeking to leave a relationship with football player Beef (Tindall) so she can get involved with Bobby Turner. At a local soda shop, Babe advises Pat not to lose her temper. ("Pass the Peace Pipe") Connie grows attracted to Tommy, who she feels is not interested. ("Just Imagine") Tommy asks Connie to the prom, but reneges when Pat shows interest. He changes his mind again. In the end, Tait wins the big game, Tommy pairs off with Connie, Beef pairs off with Pat, and Babe pairs off with Bobby Turner. The college bursts out into song in a production number. ("Varsity Drag") ==Cast== {{div col|colwidth=30em}} * [[June Allyson]] as Connie Lane * [[Peter Lawford]] as Tommy Marlowe * [[Patricia Marshall]] as Pat McClellan * [[Joan McCracken]] as Babe Doolittle * Ray McDonald as Bobby Turner * [[Mel Torm√©]] (billed as Mel Torm√©) as Danny * [[Robert E. Strickland]] (billed as Robert Strickland) as Peter Van Dyne III * [[Donald MacBride]] as Coach Johnson * [[Tom Dugan (actor, born 1889)|Tom Dugan]] as Pooch * [[Clinton Sundberg]] as Professor Burton Kennyon * [[Loren Tindall]] as Beef * [[Connie Gilchrist]] as Cora the cook * [[Morris Ankrum]] as Dean Griswold * [[Georgia Lee]] as Flo * Jane Green as Mrs. Drexel {{div col end}} ==Soundtrack== {{div col|colwidth=30em}} * "Good News" ** Music by [[Ray Henderson]] ** Lyrics by [[Lew Brown]] and [[Buddy G. DeSylva]] ** Sung by [[Joan McCracken]] and chorus * "Tait Song" ** Music by Ray Henderson ** Lyrics by Lew Brown and Buddy G. DeSylva ** Performed by Joan McCracken and chorus * "Be a Ladies' Man" ** Music by Ray Henderson ** Lyrics by Lew Brown and Buddy G. DeSylva ** Performed by [[Peter Lawford]], Ray McDonald, [[Mel Torm√©]], and Lon Tindal * "Lucky in Love" ** Music by Ray Henderson ** Lyrics by Lew Brown and Buddy G. DeSylva ** Performed by Patricia Marshall, Joan McCracken, Mel Torm√©, June Allyson, and Peter Lawford * "The French Lesson" ** Written by [[Roger Edens]], [[Betty Comden]], and [[Adolph Green]] ** Performed by June Allyson and Peter Lawford * "[[The Best Things in Life Are Free (1927 song)|The Best Things in Life Are Free]]" ** Music by Ray Henderson ** Lyrics by Lew Brown and Buddy G. DeSylva ** Performed by June Allyson ** Performed also by Mel Torm√© * "Pass That Peace Pipe" ** Written by Roger Edens, [[Hugh Martin]], and [[Ralph Blane]] ** Performed by Joan McCracken, Ray McDonald, and chorus * "Just Imagine" ** Music by Ray Henderson ** Lyrics by Lew Brown and Buddy G. DeSylva ** Sung by June Allyson * "Varsity Drag" ** Music by Ray Henderson ** Lyrics by Lew Brown and Buddy G. DeSylva ** Performed by June Allyson, Peter Lawford, and chorus {{div col end}} ===Deleted song=== "An Easier Way", sung by June Allyson and Patricia Marshall, was filmed but cut from the released version. This musical number survives and is included as an "extra" on the DVD.[http://www.dvdverdict.com/reviews/goodnews.php ''Good News'' at DVD Verdict] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070409152402/http://www.dvdverdict.com/reviews/goodnews.php |date=2007-04-09 }}[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yriWzRKkBnw June Allyson and Patricia Marshall - audio pre-recording of "An Easier Way"] on [[YouTube]] ==Reception== ===Box office=== The film was a [[box office bomb|box office disappointment]], earning $2,545,000 in the US and Canada and $411,000 elsewhere, recording a loss of $7,000.{{cite book|first=Scott|last=Eyman|title=Lion of Hollywood: The Life and Legend of Louis B. Mayer|publisher=Robson|date=2005|page=401}}[https://archive.org/stream/variety173-1949-01#page/n45/mode/1up "Top Grossers of 1948", ''Variety'' 5 January 1949 p 46] ===Awards=== Edens, Martin and Blane were nominated for the [[Academy Award for Best Song]] for "Pass That Peace Pipe". ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{IMDb title|0039431|Good News}} * {{Allmovie title|id=20312|title=Good News}} * {{Tcmdb title|id=14616|title=Good News}} * {{AFI film|id=25184|title=Good News}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070409152402/http://www.dvdverdict.com/reviews/goodnews.php DVD information about the 1947 film version] {{Charles Walters}} {{Arthur Freed}} [[Category:1947 films]] [[Category:1940s musical films]] [[Category:1940s sports films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:American football films]] [[Category:American musical comedy films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Films based on musicals]] [[Category:Films directed by Charles Walters]] [[Category:Films produced by Arthur Freed]] [[Category:Films set in 1927]] [[Category:Films set in the Roaring Twenties]] [[Category:Films set in universities and colleges]] [[Category:Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer films]]

{{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Banvit Kara Ali Acar Sport Hall
Banvit Kara Ali Acar Spor Salonu | image = Kara Ali Acar Sport Hall.png | location = [[Bandƒ±rma]], [[Balƒ±kesir Province]], [[Turkey]] | coordinates={{coord|40.33860|N|27.98688|E|type:landmark_scale:3000|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = | opened = 2001 | owner = | architect = | contractor = | tenants = [[Banvitspor]] ([[Turkish Basketball League|TBL]])
[[Bandƒ±rma Kƒ±rmƒ±zƒ±]] ([[Turkish Basketball Second League|TB2L]]) | seating_capacity = [[Basketball]]: 3,000 }} '''Banvit Kara Ali Acar Sport Hall''' is an [[indoor arena]] located in the [[Bandƒ±rma]] town of [[Balƒ±kesir Province]], [[Turkey]]. The arena mostly hosts [[basketball]] games and is the home arena of the [[Banvitspor]] and [[Bandƒ±rma Kƒ±rmƒ±zƒ±]] basketball teams. It has a seating capacity for 3,000 spectators.[http://www.eurocupbasketball.com/eurocup/games/results/showgame?clubcode=BAN&gamecode=71&seasoncode=U2012#!boxscore EurocupBasketball.com Banvit BK Bandirma 70 - 84 Valencia Basket Attendance: 3000.][http://www.eurocupbasketball.com/eurocup/games/results/showgame?clubcode=BAN&gamecode=129&seasoncode=U2012#!boxscore Banvit BK Bandirma 94 - 85 BC Budivelnik Kiev EurocupBasketball.com Attendance: 3000.] ==History== Kara Ali Acar Sport Hall opened in the year 2001. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20130204075353/http://www.banvitbasketbol.com/foto-galeri-detay/221/banvit-basketbol-kulubu-tesisleri/1 Banvit Kara Ali Acar Sport Hall Photo Gallery {{tr icon}}.] [[Category:Basketball venues in Turkey]] [[Category:Sport in Balƒ±kesir]] [[Category:Indoor arenas in Turkey]] [[Category:Turkish Basketball League venues]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Balƒ±kesir Province]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2001]] [[Category:2001 establishments in Turkey]] {{Turkey-sports-venue-stub}}
