==Short Mat Players Tour== {{main article|Short Mat Players Tour}}
The Short Mat Players Tour (SMPT),<ref>{{cite web|title=Short Mat Players Tour|url=https://shortmatplayerstour.com|website=Short Mat Players Tour|accessdate=10 July 2017}}</ref> is a company responsible of events set up by Craig Burgess and Simon Pridham in 2011.<ref name="SMPTComp">{{cite web | url=https://beta.companieshouse.gov.uk/company/08311534/officers | title=Short mat Players Tour LTD | publisher=Companies House | accessdate=October 20, 2017}}</ref> The SMPT are responsible for running events throughout Europe, the first to establish a [[world ranking]] system.<ref name="BowlsChat">{{cite web | url=https://bowlschat.com/videos/official-short-mat/short-mat-players-tour | title=Short Mat Players Tour - Bowls Chat | publisher=Bowls Chat | accessdate=October 20, 2017}}</ref>
== International Short Mat Open == The International Open was the biggest open competition in Short Mat Bowls when it first started in 2010. The competition was organised by Craig Burgess and Barry Hedges of Essex; both of the trophies awarded are in memory of their fathers, John Burgess and David Hedges. The inaugural event was held at Kempston Indoor Bowls Club, [[Bedford]], England, and had the biggest gathering of short mat bowls talent from all over Europe including England, Ireland, Wales, Scotland, Belgium and Sweden. In subsequent years, the John Burgess Trophy became a pairs event instead of the original triples format. The event finished in 2013.
{| class="wikitable" |- ! Year ! Venue ! John Burgess Trophy ! David Hedges Trophy |- | 2013 | Havering Indoor Bowls Club, [[Essex]] | {{flagathlete|Allan Williams & James Trott|ENG}} | {{flagathlete|Peter Fautley, Tony Elham, Steve Killington & Anthony Fautley |ENG}} |- | 2012 | Havering Indoor Bowls Club, Essex | {{flagathlete|Joseph Newsome & Ben Render|ENG}} | {{flagathlete|Sarah Beynon, Arwel Morgan, Tom Jones & Luke Haddon|WAL}} |- | 2011 | Havering Indoor Bowls Club, Essex | {{flagathlete|Jack Shepherd & Chris Willies|ENG}} | {{flagathlete|Steve Proctor, Andrew Beard, Gareth Stanway & Grant Soller|ENG}} |- | 2010 | Kempston Indoor Bowls Club, Bedford | {{flagathlete|Marty Trainor, Alan Paul & Kevin Conroy|IRE}} | {{flagathlete|Liam McHugh, Keith McCullagh,Damian McElroy & Colum McHugh|IRE}} |}
==St Georges Cup - (North v South)== The St Georges Cup began in 2011, with 32 players from the North of England against 32 players from the South of England in a [[Ryder Cup]]-style event.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://stgeorgescup.co.uk/hall%20of%20fame-2.html|title=Hall of fame|publisher=St Georges Cup}}</ref>
{| class="wikitable" |- ! Year ! Venue ! Winners ! Final Score |- | 2017-16 | [[Bromsgrove]] Indoor Bowls Club | North of England | '''39''' - 29 |- | 2016-15 | [[Solihull]] Indoor Bowls Club | South of England | 25 - '''43''' |- | 2015-14 | Bromsgrove Indoor Bowls Club | South of England | 20.5 - '''43.5''' |- | 2013-14 | Bromsgrove Indoor Bowls Club | Draw | 32 - 32 |- | 2012-13 | [[Tamworth, Staffordshire|Tamworth]] Indoor Bowls Club | South of England | 26 - '''38''' |- | 2011-12 | Wey Valley Indoor Bowls Club, [[Guildford]] | South of England | 20.5 - '''43.5''' |- | 2010-11 | Erdington Indoor Bowls Club, [[Birmingham]] | South of England | 21 - '''35''' |}
==English Inter County Championship== The ESMBA organise an inter-county championship for teams of 20 players from each county. Most counties will enter two teams, a first 'premier' team, and an 'A team'. Winners of the premier competition are invited to the Top County competition, where the winners of the English ICC play the Welsh & Irish winners. /* Types of sports */
revision.text:
{{Marketing}} '''Sports marketing''' is a subdivision of [[marketing]] which focuses both on the promotion of sports events and teams as well as the promotion of other products and services through sporting events and sports teams. It is a service in which the element promoted can be a physical product or a brand name. The goal is to provide the client with strategies to promote sports or to promote some other product, service, business or cause through sports. Sports marketing is also designed to meet the needs and wants of the consumers through exchange processes.<ref name="Administraci√≥n de Servicios">{{cite book |last1= Lovelock|first1= Christopher|editor1-first=Christopher |editor1-last= Lovelock |last2= Reynoso|first2= Javier|editor2-first= Javier |editor2-last= Reynoso|last3= D'Andrea|first3= Guillermo|editor3-first=Guillermo|editor3-last= D'Andrea |last4= Huete|first4= Luis|editor4-first= Luis |display-editors = 3 |editor4-last= Huete|title= Administraci√≥n de Servicios |trans-title= Service's Administration |url= |accessdate= |volume= |year= 2004 |month= |publisher= Pearson Educaci√≥n Times |location= |language= spanish |isbn=978-0-273-68826-6|page= |pages= 760|trans-chapter= }}</ref> These strategies follow the traditional four "P"'s of general [[marketing]] Product, Price, Promotion and Place; another four "P"‚Äôs are added to sports marketing, relating to the fact sports are considered to be a service. The additional 4 P‚Äôs are: Planning, Packaging, Positioning and Perception. The addition of the four extra elements is called the "sports [[marketing mix]]."<ref name="The Marketing of Sport">{{cite book |last1= Beech|first1= John|editor1-first=John |editor1-last= Beech |last2= Chadwick|first2= Simon|editor2-first= Simon |editor2-last= Chadwick|title= The marketing of Sport |trans-title= |url= |accessdate= |volume= |year= 2006 |month= |publisher= Prentice Hall and Financial Times |location= |isbn=978-0-273-68826-6|page= |pages= 592|trans-chapter= }}</ref>
Sports marketing is an element of sports promotion which involves a wide variety of sectors of the [[sports industry]], including [[sports broadcasting|broadcasting]], advertising, social media, digital platforms, ticket sales, and community relations.<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|title = Sport Marketing, 4th Edition|last = Mullin, B. J., Hardy, S., & Sutton, W.|publisher = Human Kinetics|year = 2014|isbn = |location = |pages = }}</ref>
Sports marketing is divided into three sectors. The first is the advertising of sport and sports associations such as the Olympics, Spanish Football league and the NFL, as well as sport teams like Real Madrid and the New York Yankees. The second concerns the use of sporting events, sporting teams and individual athletes to promote various products. The third category is the promotion of sports to the public in order to increase participation.
In the first case, the promotion is directly related to sports. In the second case, the products can but do not have to be directly related to sports. When the promotion is about sports in general, the use of this kind of strategy is called ‚ÄúMarketing of Sports.‚Äù When the promotion is not about the sports but sports events, athletes, teams or leagues are used to promote different products, the marketing strategy is denominated ‚ÄúMarketing through sports."<ref>{{Cite book|title = Sport marketing: Managing the exchange process|last = Milne, G. R., & McDonald, M. A.|publisher = Jones & Bartlett Learning|year = 1999|isbn = |location = |pages = }}</ref> When the promotion is about increasing participation among the public, it is called "Grassroots Sports Marketing."<ref name=":0" /> To promote the products or services, the companies and associations use different channels such as sponsorships of teams or athletes, television or radio advertisement during the different broadcast sports events and celebrations, and/or advertisement on sporting venues.
‚ÄúStreet marketing of sports‚Äù considers sports marketing through billboards on the street and also through urban elements (street lighters and sidewalks, etc.) to help promote and gain publicity during major worldwide sporting events such as the Football World Cup, the Olympic Games, or the Super Bowl.<ref name=":0" />
== Sports fans == Like all business sectors, sports businesses also rely on market segmentation to effectively market themselves.<ref>{{Cite journal|url = |title = Recreational soccer participants as potential consumers of professional soccer games ‚Äì Segmenting based on general characteristics|author1=Tokuyama, S. |author2=Greenhalgh, G. |date = 2014|journal = Journal of Contemporary Athletics|doi = |pmid = |access-date = }}</ref> Sport fans differ according to a number of attributes including motivations to attend sporting events,<ref>{{Cite journal|url = |title = Motivational profiles of sport fans of different sports|last = Wann, D. L., Grieve, F. G., Zapalac, R. K., & Pease, D. G.|date = 2008|journal = Sport Marketing Quarterly|volume=17 |issue=1 |pages= 6‚Äì19|doi = |pmid = |access-date = }}</ref> emotional attachment,<ref>{{Cite journal|url = |title = The tie that blinds? Developing and validating a scale to measure emotional attachment to a sport team|last = Dwyer, B., Mudrick, M., Greenhalgh, G. P., LeCrom, C. W., & Drayer, J.|date = 2015|journal = Sport Management Review|volume=18 |issue=4 |pages= 570‚Äì582|doi = 10.1016/j.smr.2015.01.001|pmid = |access-date = }}</ref> economic attachment,<ref>{{Cite journal|url = |title = Sport consumer typologies: A critical review|last = Stewart, B., Smith, A. C., & Nicholson, M.|date = 2003|journal = Sport Marketing Quarterly|volume=12 |issue=4 |pages= 206‚Äì216|doi = |pmid = |access-date = }}</ref> identity,<ref>{{Cite journal|url = |title = Sports fans: Measuring degree of identification with their team|last = Wann, D. L., & Branscombe, N. R.|date = 1993|journal = International Journal of Sport Psychology|volume=2 |issue=4 |pages= 1‚Äì17|doi = |pmid = |access-date = }}</ref> and loyalty.<ref>{{Cite journal|url = |title = The psychological continuum model: A conceptual framework for understanding an individual's psychological connection to sport|last = Funk, D. C., & James, J.|date = 2001|journal = Sport Management Review|volume=4 |issue=2 |pages= 119‚Äì150|doi = 10.1016/s1441-3523(01)70072-1|pmid = |access-date = }}</ref> These attributes also make sports different than other forms of entertainment as sport fans behave differently than consumers of other products and services.<ref>{{Cite journal|url = |title = Exploring Fan Behavior: Developing a Scale to Measure Sport eFANgelism|last = Dwyer, B., Greenhalgh, G. P., & LeCrom, C. W.|date = 2015|journal = Journal of Sport Management|volume=2 |issue=9 |pages= 642‚Äì656|doi = |pmid = |access-date = }}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|url = |title = Understanding the positive social psychological benefits of sport team identification: The team identification-social psychological health model|last = Wann, D. L.|date = 2006|journal = Group Dynamics: Theory, Research, and Practice|volume=10 |issue=4 |pages= 272‚Äì296.|doi = 10.1037/1089-2699.10.4.272|pmid = |access-date = }}</ref>
Attributes such as loyalty can be recognized through the contracts players and athletes sign with sports companies in which they get paid to wear or use their products in each game or sporting event. By doing so, the players and athletes and also their fans develop a loyalty for the products for a longer time.<ref name="The Marketing of Sport" /><ref>{{cite book|author1=Lynn R. Kahle |author2=Angeline G. Close |title=Consumer Behavior Knowledge for Effective Sports and Event Marketing|year=2011|location=New York|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-0-415-87358-1}}</ref>
== Types of sports == With such an array of differences of sports fans, different types and levels of sports are found across the globe. For example, in many countries cricket and football are extremely popular while in the United States American football, baseball, and basketball are most favored<ref>{{Cite web|url = https://www.economist.com/blogs/gametheory/2011/09/ranking-sports%E2%80%99-popularity|title = And the silver goes to ...|date = |access-date = |website = |publisher = }}</ref> while college sports are also preferred.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.bbcamerica.com/shows/blog/2014/03/americas-big-business-college-football-alien-concept-brits|title = America‚Äôs big business of college football? It‚Äôs a foreign concept for Brits|date = |access-date = |website = |publisher = }}</ref> In addition to the classification of sports by levels, sports have also been classified as either mainstream or non-mainstream, also known as niche.
There are seven product attributes that differentiate mainstream sports from non-mainstream sports: accessibility, popularity, uniqueness, affordability, star power, player skill, and player similarity. Accessibility, affordability, and similarity are strongly related to niche sports while popularity, player skill as well as accessibility are strongly related to mainstream sports.<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|url = |title = Spectator support: Examining the attributes that differentiate niche from mainstream sports|last = Greenhalgh, G. P., Simmons, J. M., Hambrick, M. E., & Greenwell, T. C.|date = 2011|journal = Sport Marketing Quarterly|volume=20 |issue=1 |pages= 41‚Äì52|doi = |pmid = |access-date = }}</ref> Meanwhile, fans that are less-identified with a team are drawn to player similarity as they feel they can relate more with players while highly identified fans prefer the star power of players. Affordability also is a distinguishing factor among fans, as less-identified fans place greater importance on price.<ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|url = |title = Consumption of niche sports: Understanding which product attributes predict consumption across different levels of team identification|last = Simmons, J. M., Greenwell, T. C., Thorn, D. F., Hambrick, M. E., & Greenhalgh, G.|date = 2013|journal = International Journal of Sport Management and Marketing|volume=13 |issue=3‚Äì4|pages=239‚Äì256|doi = 10.1504/ijsmm.2013.059723|pmid = |access-date = }}</ref> A practical marketing example of this is the National Lacrosse League mandating players to attend receptions of restaurants who sponsor the team.<ref name=":1" /> Other strategies that niche sports utilize to differentiate themselves from mainstream sports are providing easy access to team and player information, especially online, as well as offer affordable ticket prices and valuable promotions such as dollar beer nights and 25-cent hot dog nights.<ref name=":1" /> In contrast, popular mainstream sports like Major League Baseball (MLB) and the National Basketball Association (NBA) highlight the star power of players, which is why teams go to great effort to promote their best players. This is also seen in media as nationally televised sporting events often promote specific players leading up to games.
Fans also hold different expectations of different sport types and levels of sports, which is essential for sport marketers to understand. For example, fans attending a minor league baseball game will compare their experience to previous games attended at minor league baseball games, or even other minor league sports if they have little experience with minor league baseball. They will not, however, compare a minor league baseball experience to an NFL game as they understand the two experiences will be very different.<ref>{{Cite journal|url = |title = Understanding Spectator Expectations: An analysis of niche sports|last = Greenwell, T. C., Greenhalgh, G., & Stover, N.|date = 2013|journal = International Journal of Sport Management and Marketing |volume=13 |issue=3‚Äì4 |pages= 144|doi =10.1504/IJSMM.2013.059720 |pmid = |access-date = }}</ref>
Sports differentiation is also important concerning sponsorship. Companies who sponsor niche sports place the most importance on attributes including cost effectiveness, spectator demographics, and the company fit with the sports image.<ref>{{Cite journal|url = |title = Professional niche sports sponsorship: An investigation of sponsorship selection criteria|last = Greenhalgh, G. P., & Greenwell, T. C.|date = 2013|journal = International Journal of Sports Marketing and Sponsorship|volume=14 |issue=2 |pages= 2‚Äì19|doi = 10.1108/ijsms-14-02-2013-b002|pmid = |access-date = }}</ref> Niche sports often allow companies who cannot afford to sponsor mainstream sports a channel to market their companies. Also, with niche sports shown to attract a different type of consumer,<ref name=":2" /> these companies desire to increase their public awareness within a specific target market.<ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|url = |title = What's in it for me? An investigation of North American professional niche sport sponsorship objectives|last = Greenhalgh, G., & Greenwell, T. C.|date = 2013|journal = Sport Marketing Quarterly|volume=22 |issue=2 |pages= 101‚Äì112|doi = |pmid = |access-date = }}</ref> Other attributes important to companies sponsoring niche sports are enhancing both their image and community involvement,<ref name=":3" /> which may be easier to do through niche sports than mainstream sports.
==Benefits of sports marketing== [[File:NASCARfender.jpg|thumb|240px|right|Stickers on a NASCAR race car from companies with large advertising contracts.]] The benefits of sports marketing are wide-ranging. Stakeholders involved in sports include leagues, teams, athletes, and fans as well as cities and countries hosting sporting events. The media and businesses who promote their products and services through sports also receive benefits. Direct benefits to leagues, teams, and athletes include revenue from tickets, media rights, and sponsorships. Cities and countries also receive revenue from taxes, and all of the stakeholders gain from the exposure provided through sports.<ref>{{Cite journal|url = |title = What is the sports product and who buys it? The marketing of professional sports leagues|last = S. Mason, D.|date = 1999|journal = European Journal of Marketing|volume=33 |issue=3‚Äì4 |pages=402‚Äì419|doi = 10.1108/03090569910253251|pmid = |access-date = }}</ref>
==New challenges for sports marketing== With millennials switching to new platforms to access sport, the role of traditional media and sports marketing is changing. Outmoded inflexible contracts can leave little budget for the all-important activation, and with fans choosing rival unofficial channels for gossip and insider information, the rewards can be hard won. New and accessible ways to view sports, from mobile to social to VR, means there is less incentive for fans to attend events in person, while more expectation is placed on sports stars to pull off an authentic natural voice for their brands.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.campaignlive.co.uk/article/need-know-sports-marketing-2017-beyond/1424873#mainchallenges|title=What you need to know about sports marketing in 2017 and beyond|author=|date=|website=campaignlive.co.uk|accessdate=19 April 2018}}</ref> The environment is extremely tough for small college athletics (e.g., NCAA Division III schools), who rely on fan attendance for revenue generation to keep their sports afloat - requiring communicators and marketers to become more creative in the ways they promote sports to their target audiences.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Perrault|first=Evan K.|date=2016-09-01|title=Attitudes and Motivations of Students Toward Athletic-Event Attendance at a Midsize Division III University: Recommendations for Communicators|url=http://journals.humankinetics.com/doi/10.1123/ijsc.2016-0011|journal=International Journal of Sport Communication|volume=9|issue=3|pages=321‚Äì339|doi=10.1123/ijsc.2016-0011|issn=1936-3915}}</ref>
==The marketing of sports teams and events== According to different authors and organizations, the marketing of sports events and teams is defined as ‚ÄúDesigning or developing a 'live' themed activity, occasion, display, or exhibit a sporting event to promote a product, a team, cause, or organization. In other words it can be defined as follows: The marketing of sports events and teams is the marketing strategy which is designed or developed for a ‚Äúlive‚Äù activity, which has a specific theme. Mostly this kind of strategy is used as a way to promote, display or exhibit different things, such as a sports team, a sport association among others. There are different events that can clearly exemplify this concept, such as the [[Super Bowl]], the [[Olympic Games]], the [[UEFA Champions League]], the [[World Marathon Majors]], and the [[FIFA World Cup]].<ref name="Definition marketing of sport event">{{cite web |url=http://www.businessdictionary.com/definition/event-marketing.html |title=Event marketing |author=Business dictionary.com |date=5 November 2010 |publisher=Bisnessdictionary.com |trans-title= Definicion de marketing de un evento |accessdate= November 5, 2010}}</ref>
Major sports brands compete to link up with the best marathons in the world, the test for excellence in ‚Äòrunning‚Äô, in what is a genuine showcase for strengthening its [[marketing strategy]] to its target audience. [[Adidas]]''',''' [[ASICS|Asics]] and [[Nike, Inc.|Nike]] are dividing the market into the ‚Äò[[World Marathon Majors]]'''‚Äô''', the international athletics competition created in 2006 that brings together the most prestigious [[marathon]]s on the planet. They are not title but technical sponsors, but these runs are popular and are not to be missed events for these brands, which create specific [[advertising campaign]]s to one of the few competitions that brings together professionals and amateurs under the same chrono.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://johancruyffinstitute.com/en/blog-en/nothing-is-impossible-in-sports-marketing/|title=Nothing is impossible in sports marketing|date=|website=|publisher=Johan Cruyff Institute|access-date=}}</ref>
The Super Bowl is an example of this concept because it is a massive sports event organized by a sport association, the NFL, which looks to promote the event, the sport, and as well the different football teams. The event is promoted through local and national media, and has also spread internationally. For example, in Mexico the NFL signed a contract with [[Cinemex]], a Mexican movie theater chain, for the right to transmit its games in movie theaters. This displays the potential of sporting leagues and teams to promote not just the event, but the league and teams involved to a worldwide audience.<ref name="NFL and Cinemex">{{cite web |url=http://blog.luismaram.com/2006/09/07/la-nfl-en-cinemex/ |title=La NFL en Cinemex |author=Luis Maram |date=7 September 2010|publisher= Luis Maram|language=Spanish |trans-title= The NFL in Cinemex |accessdate=November 5, 2010}}</ref>
==The marketing of products through sports== ''''Marketing through sports'''' is a concept that's been used since the 1980s, but has increased in importance in the last two decades due to the growth and expansion that the different types of sports have enjoyed since then. ‚ÄúMarketing through sports‚Äù it is a marketing strategy that can be used in sports in two different ways. First, the use of marketing and promotion can be carried out through the sport or through the sports club. In the first case, the use of marketing is under responsibility of the different sporting associations, while in the second case, the responsibility falls on the different sports clubs. In this manner, marketing and promotion through sports and through the club involve sponsorship, corporate events and boxes, licensed merchandise, names and images also known as ‚Äúendorsement‚Äù, advertising through broadcaster, advertising such as advertising as ground signage/clothing/equipment advertising, promoting games, promoting using players/club/league or developing ‚Äòbusiness opportunities.‚Äô The peculiarity of sports is that ‚Äúsports is the only entertainment where, no matter how many times you go back, you never know the ending.‚Äù This singular fact is used by marketing companies as an advantage: every time the audience attends an event it will see the advertisements again and again, providing a wide range of opportunities for the different companies which operate in this field.<ref name="The Marketing of Sport"/>
===Examples of marketing of products through sports===
==== Sponsorship of events ==== One of the oldest examples of the marketing of products through sports is [[Slazenger|Slazenger‚Äôs]] supplying of the official ball of Wimbledon (1902- 2015<ref>{{cite web|url=http://store.slazenger.com/CustomerServices/OtherInformation/AboutUs|title=About Us - Slazenger|author=|date=|website=store.slazenger.com|accessdate=19 April 2018}}</ref>).Another international example of marketing products through sport is Adidas‚Äô sponsorship of FIFA, which includes the company supplying the balls used in the World Cup and having its logo on the side boards along the play-field.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://qz.com/233611/adidas-won-the-world-cup-battle-but-nike-is-winning-the-soccer-wars/|title = Adidas won the World Cup battle, but Nike is winning the soccer wars|date = |access-date = |website = |publisher = }}</ref> In what it described as a "world first" in corporate sports sponsorship,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bnymellon.com/us/en/events/boatrace.jsp|title=BNY Mellon & Newton Pull Together for Cancer Research UK|author=|date=|website=bnymellon.com|accessdate=19 April 2018}}</ref> in 2016 [[BNY Mellon]] and [[Newton Investment Management]] announced they had donated their title sponsorship of the annual Oxford and Cambridge [[The Boat Race|Boat Races]] to [[Cancer Research UK]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bnymellon.com/emea/en/_locale-assets/pdf/who-we-are/bny-mellon-newton-pull-together-for-cancer-research-uk.pdf|title=BNY Mellon and Cancer Research UK Boat Race sponsorship details|author=|date=|website=bnymellon.com|accessdate=19 April 2018|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160404093455/https://www.bnymellon.com/emea/en/_locale-assets/pdf/who-we-are/bny-mellon-newton-pull-together-for-cancer-research-uk.pdf|archivedate=4 April 2016|df=}}</ref>
====Sponsorship of teams==== Sponsorship of teams is found throughout sports. Some of the most visible examples are found in the MLS as company names and logos are featured on team jerseys. For example, Alaska Airlines is the official jersey sponsor of the Portland Timbers while Valspar is the official sponsor of the Chicago Fire. These are examples of sponsorships of companies that are not related to sports.
Turkish Airlines established a sports marketing strategy involving high-profile sports teams, players, and sport associations including Manchester United, FC Barcelona, the Euroleague basketball competition, NBA player Kobe Bryant, the Turkey national football team, and tennis player Caroline Wozniacki.
Another example of sports marketing through sponsorships of teams is the apparel contracts seen throughout sports. In 2011 Nike agreed to become the official apparel company of the NFL in exchange for around $220 million per year, a deal that has been extended through 2019.
At the college level, Ohio State and Nike maintain a contract that provides the school a value of $16.8 million per year in cash and product through the 2033-34 academic year.<ref>{{Cite web|url = https://www.wsj.com/articles/nike-reaches-252-million-deal-to-extend-sponsorship-at-ohio-state-1452811305|title = Nike reaches $252 million deal to extend sponsorship at Ohio State|date = |access-date = |website = |publisher = }}</ref> Michigan meanwhile receives a total value of $15.3 million per year. Under Armour and Adidas are also major apparel brands as Under Armour sponsors Notre Dame for $9 million per year while Adidas provides more than $7 million each year to both UCLA and Louisville.
These are examples of sports marketing because as it is defined, sports marketing is a marketing strategy in which companies related to sports products or services promote their trademark through design, production or other resources. In this case apparel companies Nike, Under Armour, and Adidas, which are all completely related to sports, design the uniforms of these teams and in this way, promote their trademarks every time there is an event.
==== Sponsorship of athletes ==== Apparel companies also sponsor professional athletes such as [[Kevin Durant]] who receives $30 million per year from Nike. [[Stephen Curry]] is speculated to receive even more money than Durant from his contract with Under Armour.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.basketballinsiders.com/nba-pm-largest-nba-shoe-deals/|title = NBA PM: Largest NBA shoe deals|date = |access-date = |website = |publisher = }}</ref> Meanwhile, Puma pays sprinter Usain Bolt $10 million per year.<ref name=":4">{{Cite web|url = http://opendorse.com/blog/highest-paid-athlete-endorsers/|title = Top 100 highest-paid athlete endorsers of 2015|date = |access-date = |website = |publisher = }}</ref>
Many athletes maintain contracts with a variety of companies; some of them are related to sports and others that are not. Roger Federer holds agreements with Nike, Wilson, Rolex, Mercedes-Benz, and Gillette, worth a sum close to $60 million each year. LeBron James‚Äô contracts with Nike, Beats by Dre, Coca-Cola, Kia, McDonald‚Äôs, and Samsung accrue the NBA player more than $40 million per year.<ref name=":4" /> Peyton Manning meanwhile holds sponsorship agreements with companies including Buick, DirecTV, Gatorade, Nationwide and Papa John‚Äôs worth in sum approximately $12 million per year. Fellow NFL quarterback Drew Brees earns $11 million each year from his contracts with Wrangler, Vicks, Verizon, Nike, and Microsoft.<ref name=":4" />
Another example of marketing through sports is the strategy used by Gillette to promote its personal hygiene products through representative figures of each sport on television during broadcast sports events. Gillette uses athletes such as tennis player Roger Federer, golfer Tiger Woods, and soccer player Thierry Henry. In the commercial these celebrities appear using the products of the company. This is done in order to promote these products to the fans of these celebrities and inspire them to use these products. It is a clear example of this concept, because the company using this marketing strategy is not related to sports at all, but through important sports personalities, its products are exposed to a larger target audience.
Nike and Gatorade also hold sponsorship agreements with top athletes. Included among Nike's clients are Federer, Woods, golfer Rory McIlroy and tennis player Rafael Nadal while Gatorade has deals with NBA star Dwyane Wade, Serena Williams, and Peyton and Eli Manning.<ref name=":4" />
== The promotion of sports to the public to increase sports participation == Grassroots sports marketing is a part of the field of marketing known as social marketing. This refers to marketing something that is of benefit to the public, and is normally done by government or charities rather than private sector organizations. It is normally done with a much smaller budget than marketing of sports teams and event or marketing of products through sports as it does not bring any direct financial benefit. Although this marketing normally drives people to clubs where they will pay to play sports, it still needs to be subsidized in order to be run. The money therefore comes from local councils with a remit to increase participation or from public health sector which wants to decrease the cost of healthcare.
Examples of the promotion of sports to increase participation is the United States Golf Association‚Äôs initiatives to increase golf participation<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://thefieldsofgreen.com/2014/07/23/to-increase-participation-usga-promotes-nine-hole-golf/|title = To increase participation, USGA promotes nine-hole golf|date = |access-date = |website = |publisher = }}</ref> as well as MLB‚Äôs One Baseball campaign, which attempts to unify baseball organizations at all levels with the overarching goal of increasing youth participation and consequently creating new fans.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.sportsbusinessdaily.com/Journal/Issues/2015/03/23/In-Depth/One-Baseball.aspx|title = MLB pushes for united front to boost baseball|date = |access-date = |website = |publisher = }}</ref>
== Relationship Marketing in Sports == [[Relationship marketing]] relates to customer retention and building long term successful relationship between a business and its customers by maximizing customer satisfaction.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Kotler|first1=P|title=The view from here. In Peppers. D., & Rogers, M. (Eds.), Managing customer relationships: A strategic framework|date=2011|publisher=Wiley|location=Hoboken, NJ|pages=1‚Äì14}}</ref> Sport businesses need to communicate and participate in discussion with their customers in order to create, sustain and improve relationships.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Sheth|first1=Jagdish N.|title=The future of relationship marketing|journal=Journal of Services Marketing|date=December 2002|volume=16|issue=7|pages=590‚Äì592|doi=10.1108/08876040210447324}}</ref> Existing studies offer insightful information into relationship marketing and the general consensus is that sports businesses can benefit from its use.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Yu|first1=K|last2=Trail|first2=G|title=A conceptual framework for understanding relationships between sport consumers and sport organizations: A relationship quality approach|journal=Journal of Sport Management|date=2011|volume=25|issue=1|pages=57‚Äì69}}</ref> In many situations, sports marketing affairs include some sort of relationship marketing, where clubs, organisations, fans and athletes have relationships with one another that are dependent on the successful management of those relationships.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Bee|first1=C|last2=Khale|first2=R|title=Relationship marketing in sports: A functional approach|journal=Sport Marketing Quarterly|date=2006|volume=15|issue=2|pages=102‚Äì110}}</ref> In order for sport businesses to be successful in their goals, they should view their customers as partners for life rather than here and now consumers, and attempt to understand their ever-evolving needs, desires, expectations and values. By doing so, sport businesses are able to maintain and enhance their fan base easily than through the more commonly used short-term transactions such as merchandise and ticket sales.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Abeza|first1=G|last2=O'Reilly|first2=N|last3=Reid|first3=I|title=Relationship Marketing and Social Media in Sport‚Äô|journal=International Journal of Sport Communication|date=2013|volume=6|issue=2|pages=120‚Äì142|doi=10.1123/ijsc.6.2.120}}</ref> Social media enables businesses to do this and connect with their customers with much higher efficiency and effectiveness.
== Social Media and relationship marketing in sports == Used as a global communication and interaction channel, social media has changed the conventional business customer relationship dynamics. Social media is a tool that enables customers‚Äô engagement through an instantaneous and active back-to-back conversation.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Drury|first1=Glen|title=Opinion piece: Social media: Should marketers engage and how can it be done effectively?|journal=Journal of Direct, Data and Digital Marketing Practice|date=4 January 2008|volume=9|issue=3|pages=274‚Äì277|doi=10.1057/palgrave.dddmp.4350096}}</ref> Customers are increasingly incorporating social media into their daily lives and using it for communication. Businesses have also made it an integral part of their communication mix.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Mangold|first1=C|last2=Faulds|first2=D|title=Social media: The new hybrid element of the promotion mix|journal=Business Horizons|date=2009|volume=52|issue=4|pages=357‚Äì365|doi=10.1016/j.bushor.2009.03.002}}</ref> Today, sports businesses can use social media to actively listen to their customers, recognise and follow their specific needs and wants <ref>{{cite journal|last1=Williams|first1=J|last2=Chinn|first2=S.J.|title=Meeting relationship-marketing goals through social media: A conceptual model for sport marketers|journal=International Journal of Sport Communication|date=2010|volume=3|issue=4|pages=422‚Äì437|doi=10.1123/ijsc.3.4.422}}</ref> rather than use out-dated methods of data collection such as surveys and focus groups, which do not provide rich information to better understand customers. It allows sports businesses to keep their customers updated on the latest news and information as well as interact with them on an individual basis.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Askool|first1=S,|last2=Nakata|first2=K,|title=A conceptual model for acceptance of social CRM systems based on a scoping study|journal=AI & Society|date=2011|volume=26|issue=3|pages=205‚Äì220|doi=10.1007/s00146-010-0311-5}}</ref> This instantaneous two-way communication tool available to sports businesses allows them to provide quality content within short time frames and interact with customers in real time. In terms of marketing, this can also be seen as a form of competitive advantage. They are able to interact the way they want, in the way they wish, using the medium they like most. This gives sports businesses additional edge in terms of marketing. Effective utilization of social media enables sports brands to provide their customers with the best possible experience and expand their marketing capabilities.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Woodcock|first1=N|last2=Broomfield|first2=N|last3=Downer|first3=G|last4=Starkey|first4=M|title=The evolving data architecture of social customer relationship management|journal=Journal of Direct Data and Digital Marketing Practice|date=2011|volume=12|issue=3|pages=249‚Äì266|doi=10.1057/dddmp.2010.45}}</ref>
The benefits of social media are for both sides. Apart from sports businesses benefiting from the use of social media in the context of relationship management and marketing, customers also get to experience the same level of benefits. The constant interaction between sport businesses and their customers allows organisations to know and learn about each individual customer on a deeper level. As a result of this, customers feel more valued and this leads to higher customer loyalty.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Peppers|first1=D|last2=Roggers|first2=M|title=Managing customer relationships: A strategic framework|date=2011|publisher=Wiley|location=Hoboken, NJ}}</ref> Social media enables sport businesses to involve customers in the marketing process by receiving feedback and ideas, which can then be implemented in future products and services. By doing so, sport businesses strengthen the level of engagement and connection between the organisation and the customer,<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Miller|first1=R|last2=Rogers|first2=M|title=Social media and its implications for viral marketing|journal=Asia Pacific Public Relations Journal|date=2010|volume=11|issue=1|pages=1‚Äì9}}</ref> and this reinforces the importance that customers hold in the brand building process.
== Sports marketing through social media == Professional leagues, teams, and athletes have started using social media as a part of their marketing strategies during the recent years. The most popular social media platforms are Facebook and Twitter, but athletes and teams are also using sites including Instagram and Snapchat for marketing.<ref>{{Cite web|url = https://www.forbes.com/sites/markfidelman/2014/07/28/8-lessons-from-sports-marketing-experts-for-brands-and-athletes-resisting-move-to-digital/#2715e4857a0b140cf25b6409|title = 8 lessons from sports marketing experts for brands and athletes resisting move to digital|date = |access-date = |website = |publisher = }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.venustrappedinmars.com/2015/11/athlete-pro-sports-teams-snapchat.html|title = The complete list of your favorite pro teams' Snapchat handles|date = |access-date = |website = |publisher = }}</ref> As in case of all businesses, the advantages of social media use in sports include building brand awareness, reaching a larger audience in an easy and cost-effective way<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.socialmediaelearning.co.uk/6-advantages-of-social-media-marketing/|title = 6 advantages of using social media marketing for your business|date = |access-date = |website = |publisher = }}</ref> as well as creating brand advocates and engaging passionate sports fans.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.adweek.com/sa-article/passion-fan-146722|title = The passion of the fan: Consumers want more from their sports brands...more digital content, more entertainment, more fun|date = |access-date = |website = |publisher = }}</ref> There are numerous examples of athletes and sports teams using social media for marketing and promotions.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://socialnsport.com/|title = Strong #SMSports examples of Twitter polls|date = |access-date = |website = |publisher = }}</ref>
For example, for a brand like [[Babolat]], having a world icon like [[Rafael Nadal]] as its top brand representative is priceless. There is no better way to stand up to your competition than by having the best on your side. You must also know how to do it because not everything works in marketing. This is why knowing how to use social media is fundamentally important. ‚ÄúA message on Twitter is not just an advertising channel with which you can win an audience. Its power lies in the message being relevant and credible‚Äù, explains Edwin Schravesande (professor of [[e-marketing]] at the [https://cruyffacademy.nl Johan Cruyff Academy] of Tilburg).<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://johancruyffinstitute.com/en/blog-en/the-athlete-as-a-social-media-marketing-product/|title = The athlete as a social media marketing product|date = |access-date = |website = |publisher = Johan Cruyff Institute }}</ref>
Baylor Bold Rewards Program: When fans decide to "Like" or "Follow" Baylor athletics on either Twitter or Facebook, they are given day-to-day updates on their favorite teams. From a marketing aspect, the Baylor athletics page on Facebook and Twitter (@BaylorAthletics) keeps track of fans who have "tweeted" or "commented" on certain links, posts, or tweets. There is an incentive for these fans to post and tweet because at the end of each year, the top three posting or tweeting fans are selected to receive grand prizes including free jerseys and merchandise to season tickets.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.baylorbears.com/genrel/111011aad.html|title = Baylor athletics unveils social media rewards program|date = |access-date = |website = Baylor Bears|publisher = }}</ref>
Michigan Presale Incentive: Michigan used a very clever way to increase the total amount of "likes" or "followers" for their Facebook and Twitter Pages in order to find higher recognition. In order to have the opportunity to apply for pre-sale tickets for their Michigan football games, at the largest football arena in the nation 'The Big House,' fans are required to "follow" or "like" their page on Facebook or Twitter. This allows them to be able to purchase pre-sale tickets for any game that they desire, making this method of marketing a great tool for gaining awareness for their team and many other things.{{citation needed|date=May 2017}}
Louisville Slugger Scavenger Hunt: After the St. Louis Cardinals won the World Series in 2011, Hillerich & Bradsby, makers of Louisville Slugger bats and other baseball equipment, created a scavenger hunt through Twitter in order to raise awareness for their company. The hunt involved 45 world series commemorative bats, scattered all over the city of St. Louis, Missouri. The Louisville Slugger Twitter page posted "tweets" that hinted at where the bats were located within the city. The fan or participants used their mobile phones in order to remain up to date on the specific "tweets" referring to the hunt. If a fan or participant found one of the several bats, the participant was told that they were to be kept by the seeker. The reason this company held a scavenger hunt was to find recognition and to increase their number of followers on Twitter. The statistics shows that their fan base skyrocketed, lifting the number of Facebook likes by 143%, number of people talking about the brand on Facebook by 834% and its number of Tweeter followers by 161%.<ref>{{Cite web|url = https://www.clickz.com/louisville-slugger-lifts-facebook-chatter-by-834/49051/|title = Louisville Slugger Lifts Facebook Chatter by 834%|date = |access-date = |website = Clickz|publisher = }}</ref>
Many teams have incorporated sponsorships into their social media strategies, such as the Minnesota Vikings ‚ÄúTouchdown Tracker‚Äù Instagram image, which was sponsored by FedEx. The Cleveland Browns also displayed sponsorship integration in their tweets recapping touchdown drives, sponsored by Cooper Tires.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://socialnsport.com/2015/10/|title = 5 guidelines for sponsored social content|date = |access-date = |website = |publisher = }}</ref>
Many athletes including Kobe Bryant, Russell Wilson, and Rafael Nadal have taken advantage of social media to increase their followers and improve their brand recognition.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://blog.hootsuite.com/top-athletes-social-media/|title = Six top athletes using social media to dominate|date = |access-date = |website = |publisher = }}</ref> Athletes have also promoted brands through social media including Russell Wilson‚Äôs sponsorship of Recovery Water and Serena Williams‚Äô promotion of Wheels Up.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.sesponsorshipgroup.com/sponsorship-figures/2015/9/15/a-sponsored-tweet-from-lebron-james-valued-at-140000|title = A sponsored tweet from LeBron James valued at $140,000|date = |access-date = |website = |publisher = }}</ref> Because of this marketing tool, these fan-based website pages have increased greatly in numbers and give them the recognition that they were looking for.
==References== {{reflist}}

[[Italy national football team]] (selected matches) | seating_capacity = 36,600riferimento dal sito web del club reale pi√π accurato rispetto agli altri | }} The '''Stadio Comunale Luigi Ferraris''', also known as the '''Marassi''' from the name of the neighbourhood where it is located, is a multi-use stadium in [[Genoa]], [[Italy]]. The home of [[Genoa C.F.C.]] and [[U.C. Sampdoria]] football clubs, it opened in 1911 and is one of the oldest stadiums still in use for football and other sports in Italy. Aside from football, the stadium has hosted meetings of rugby in the [[Italian National Rugby Team|Italian national team]] and, more rarely, some concerts. ==Notable matches== The stadium was inaugurated on 22 January 1911 with a football match between Genoa and [[Internazionale]], and had a capacity of 20,000. On 22 December 1912, it hosted its first international, in which [[Italy national football team|Italy]] lost 3‚Äì1 to [[Austria national football team|Austria]] in a friendly.http://eu-football.info/_venue.php?id=546 It also hosted the [[1934 FIFA World Cup|1934 World Cup]] quarter-final match between [[Spain national football team|Spain]] and [[Brazil national football team|Brazil]], and by then its capacity had been expanded to 30,000. The stadium was dismantled and rebuilt before the [[1990 FIFA World Cup]], for which it hosted three Group C matches (between [[Costa Rica national football team|Costa Rica]], [[Scotland national football team|Scotland]] and [[Sweden national football team|Sweden]]) and a round-of-16 match between the [[Republic of Ireland national football team|Republic of Ireland]] and [[Romania national football team|Romania]]. The highest attendance at the Luigi Ferraris was 60,000 on 27 February 1949, for a match between [[Italy national football team|Italy]] and [[Portugal national football team|Portugal]]. On 12 October 2010, a [[Euro 2012]] [[UEFA Euro 2012 qualifying Group C|qualifier]] between [[Italy national football team|Italy]] and [[Serbia national football team|Serbia]] was abandoned after Serbia fans continued to throw flares onto the pitch and light fireworks. When the game finally began, more flares and fireworks were thrown onto the field and the referee stopped the match after only six minutes of play.{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/9086046.stm|title=Italy-Serbia Euro 2012 tie abandoned after fan trouble |date=12 October 2010|work=BBC Sport|accessdate=12 October 2010}} On 29 February 2012, the [[United States men's national soccer team|United States]] defeated Italy 1‚Äì0 in a friendly played at the stadium. It was the first time that Italy had been defeated in Genoa and the first time that the US had ever defeated Italy.{{cite web |url=http://m.ussoccer.com/news/mens-national-team/2012/02/us-mnt-earns-first-win-against-italy.aspx |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-11-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131111164345/http://m.ussoccer.com/News/Mens-National-Team/2012/02/US-MNT-Earns-First-Win-Against-Italy.aspx |archivedate=11 November 2013 |df=dmy-all }} On November 14, 2014, it hosted [[Italy national rugby union team|Italy‚Äôs]] end-of-year rugby union international against [[Argentina national rugby union team|Argentina]] who won 20 - 18. ==Average {{Update|inaccurate=yes|article|date=March 2013}} {{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Taichung Intercontinental Baseball Stadium | nickname = | image = Âè∞‰∏≠Ê¥≤ÈöõÊ£íÁêÉÂ†¥.JPG | image_size = 300px | location = [[Taichung City]], [[Taiwan]] | coordinates = | broke_ground = February 1, 2005 | opened = November 9, 2006 | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = [http://webeng.tccg.gov.tw/ Taichung City Government] | operator = [http://webeng.tccg.gov.tw/ Taichung City Government] | surface = Grass | construction_cost = 600,000,000 [[New Taiwan dollar|NTD]] | architect = | project_manager = | main_contractors = | former_names = | tenants = | seating_capacity = 20,000 | dimensions = '''Left Field''' – {{Convert|99.1|m|ft|0}}
'''Left-Center''' – {{Convert|115.5|m|ft|0}}
'''Center Field''' – {{Convert|121.9|m|ft|0}}
'''Right-Center''' – {{Convert|115.5|m|ft|0}}
'''Right Field''' – {{Convert|99.1|m|ft|0}} }} '''Taichung Intercontinental Baseball Stadium''' ({{zh|t=Ëá∫‰∏≠Â∏ÇÊ¥≤ÈöõÊ£íÁêÉÂ†¥}}) is a stadium in [[Beitun District]], [[Taichung]], [[Taiwan]]. The stadium officially opened on November 9, 2006 replacing the antiquated [[Taichung Baseball Field]]. Located on the corner of Chongde Road (Â¥áÂæ∑Ë∑Ø) and Huanzhong Road (Áí∞‰∏≠Ë∑Ø), it has considerably more parking available than the old stadium, which will be much more convenient for fans. The stadium is a venue for [[rock concert]]s and also hosted [[Zhang Yimou]]'s [[Turandot at the Forbidden City|Turandot at the Bird's Nest]] in 2010.Âº†Ëâ∫Ë∞ãÁâà„ÄäÂõæÂÖ∞Êúµ„ÄãÂè∞Êπæ‰∏äÊºî_‰∏≠ÂõΩÂè∞ÊπæÁΩë 2010Âπ¥12Êúà17Êó• "Â§ßÂûãÊôØËßÇÊ≠åÂâß„ÄäÂõæÂÖ∞Êúµ„ÄãÂú®Âè∞‰∏≠Â∏ÇÊ¥≤ÈôÖÊ£íÁêÉÂú∫‰∏äÊºî„ÄÇ ÂΩìÊôöÔºåÂº†Ëâ∫Ë∞ã‰ª•ÊÄªÂØºÊºî Ë∫´‰ªΩËßÇÁúã‰∫ÜÊºîÂá∫„ÄÇÊ≠§Ê¨°Ëµ¥Âè∞ÊºîÂá∫ÁöÑÂà∂‰ΩúÂõ¢Èòü‰ªç‰∏∫‚ÄúÈ∏üÂ∑¢Áâà‚Äù„ÄäÂõæÂÖ∞Êúµ„Äã ==Construction== Construction on the stadium began in 2005 and is operating on the [[Build-Operate-Transfer]] (BOT) model that is becoming increasingly common among [[public works]] projects in Taiwan. The first phase includes 15,000 infield seats, all with seatback chairs. After the second phase was completed in 2008, [[seating capacity]] was expanded to 20,000 by adding 5,000 outfield seats.{{Cite web |url=http://veestadium.markwell.com.tw/?cat=20 |title=Âè∞‰∏≠Â∏ÇÊ¥≤ÈöõÊ£íÁêÉÂ†¥Á∞°‰ªã(Introduction of Taichung Intercontinental Baseball Stadium) |publisher=Taichung Intercontinental Baseball Stadium |language=Chinese |date=May 5, 2010}} ==Major events== The first major event hosted by the new stadium was the [[2006 Intercontinental Cup]], a baseball competition between eight nations from four different continents. [[Korea national baseball team|South Korea]] defeated [[Philippines national baseball team|the Philippines]] in the opener 10‚Äì0, followed by [[Chinese Taipei national baseball team|Chinese Taipei]]'s defeat against [[Italy national baseball team|Italy]] 3‚Äì13 on November 9.{{ref|bb1}} On the final day of the [[2006 Intercontinental Cup]] it was announced that the [[2007 Baseball World Cup]] will be held in Taichung, with this stadium one of the two to be used for the tournament. The stadium also hosted some games at the [[2007 Asian Baseball Championship]], which counted as the [[2008 Summer Olympics]] qualifier for the Asia region. The stadium hosted the Pool B in the first round of the [[2013 World Baseball Classic]]. ==Name confusion== From the beginning of this project, the stadium had been known as the Taichung International Standard Baseball Stadium.{{ref|name1}} However, newspaper reports had referred to it as the Taichung International Baseball Stadium, (dropping the word "Standard".){{ref|name2}} A Chinese language schedule for the [[2006 Intercontinental Cup]] had identified the stadium as the Taichung Intercontinental Stadium. According to a report in 2006, the mayor of [[Taichung]], [[Jason Hu]], announced that the name of the stadium has been officially designated as Intercontinental Baseball Stadium. This is in honor of the event being the first to be held at the stadium.{{ref|name3}} ==Miscellaneous== ===Stadium firsts=== [[File:Taichung Intercontinental Baseball Stadium01.jpg|thumb|right|First pitch in a competitive game at the stadium in a game between the Philippines and South Korea in the 2006 Intercontinental Cup]] *First competitive game: South Korea v. the Philippines; November 9, 2006. [[2006 Intercontinental Cup]]. *First win: South Korea 10 - Philippines 0; November 9, 2006. [[2006 Intercontinental Cup]] *First [[mercy rule]] win: South Korea 10 - Philippines 0; November 9, 2006. [[2006 Intercontinental Cup]] *First nine-inning shutout: *First extra-inning game: Chinese Taipei v. South Korea; November 12, 2006; [[2006 Intercontinental Cup]] *First [[home run]]: [[Bradley Harman]] (Australia) (8th inning v. Philippines); November 10, 2006 [[2006 Intercontinental Cup]] *First [[Grand slam (baseball)|grand slam]]: Chen Yung-Chi (Chinese Taipei) (7th inning v. South Korea); November 12, 2006; [[2006 Intercontinental Cup]] *First [[complete game]]: ===Stadium records=== *'''Longest game''': 13 innings – Italy v. Australia; November 12, 2006; [[2006 Intercontinental Cup]] {{ref|ITA-AUS}} *'''Runs in a game (Single Team)''': 13 – Italy v. Chinese Taipei; November 9, 2006;[http://www.baseball.ch/TPE06/bxscores/04.htm Italy v. Chinese Taipei] Netherlands v. South Korea, November 15, 2006 {{ref|NED-KOR}} [[2006 Intercontinental Cup]] *'''Runs in a game (Combined)''': 16 – Italy (13) v. Chinese Taipei (3) {{ref|ITA-TPE}}; November 9, 2006: and Chinese Taipei (9) v. South Korea (7); September 12, 2006 {{ref|KOR-TPE}}; [[2006 Intercontinental Cup]] *'''Runs in an inning (Single Team)''': 6 – Italy (3rd inning) v. Chinese Taipei, November 9, 2006{{ref|ITA-TPE}}; Australia (8th inning) v. the Philippines, November 10, 2006 {{ref|PHI-AUS}}; [[2006 Intercontinental Cup]] *'''Runs in an inning (Combined)''': 6 – Italy v. Chinese Taipei (3rd inning), November 9, 2006 {{ref|ITA-TPE}}; Australia v. the Philippines (8th inning), November 10, 2006 {{ref|PHI-AUS}}; [[2006 Intercontinental Cup]] *'''Runs in a game (Single Player)''': 2 – Numerous times *'''[[RBI]]s in a game (Single Player)''': 7 – [[Jack Murphy (baseball)|Jack Murphy]], [[Australian Baseball League|ABL]] [[Canberra Cavalry]] v [[Uni-President 7-Eleven Lions]]; 20 November 2013;[http://www.canberratimes.com.au/sport/canberra-cavalry-wins-asia-series-20131121-2xw9m.html Canberra Cavalry wins Asia Series], David Polkinghorne, [[Canberra Times]], 21 November 2013 [[2013 Asia Series]] final (won 14-4 with Murphy hitting a [[grand slam (baseball)|Grand Slam]] [[homer]] in the 8th inning) *'''[[base hit|Hits]] in a game (Single Team)''': 19 - Italy v. Chinese Taipei; November 9, 2006{{ref|ITA-TPE}}; [[2006 Intercontinental Cup]] *'''[[base hit|Hits]] in a game (Combined)''': 29 – Italy (19) v. Chinese Taipei (10); November 9, 2006 {{ref|ITA-TPE}}; Australia (10) v. South Korea (9) November 14, 2006 {{ref|KOR-AUS}} - [[2006 Intercontinental Cup]] *'''[[base hit|Hits]] in a game (Single Player)''': 3 – Numerous times *'''[[Strikeout]]s in a game (Pitching Staff)''': 12 – Cuba v. the Netherlands; November 19, 2006 {{ref|CUB-NED}} ;[[2006 Intercontinental Cup]] *'''[[Strikeout]]s in a game (Single Pitcher)''': 8 – Frank Montieh (Cuba) v. the Netherlands; November 19, 2006 {{ref|CUB-NED}}; [[2006 Intercontinental Cup]] ===Google Street View=== The stadium is accessible in Google Street View. There are 360 degree views from the pitchers mound, home plate, the bleachers and concourses. https://maps.google.com/maps?ll=24.200079,120.685242&spn=0.01,0.01&t=m&q=24.200079,120.685242 ==Notes== #{{note|bb1}} {{cite web|url=http://www.baseball.ch/TPE06/Taipei2006.pdf|format=PDF|title=XVI Intercontinental Cup|accessdate=2006-10-17 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20061107031451/http://www.baseball.ch/TPE06/Taipei2006.pdf |archivedate = 2006-11-07}} #{{note|name1}} {{cite web|url=http://www.tccg.gov.tw/sys/SM_theme?page=4292bb4b|title=Ëá∫‰∏≠Â∏ÇÂúãÈöõÊ®ôÊ∫ñÊ£íÁêÉÂ†¥ (Taichung International Standard Baseball Stadium)|accessdate=2006-10-23|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050529235834/http://www.tccg.gov.tw/sys/SM_theme?page=4292bb4b|archivedate=2005-05-29|df=}} #{{note|name2}} {{cite web|title=Ê£íÂçîÈóúÂàáÂè∞‰∏≠ÂúãÈöõÊ£íÁêÉÂ†¥ËààÂª∫ÈÄ≤Â∫¶ |url=http://www.cdns.com.tw/20051004/news/tyxw/800070002005100317462571.htm|accessdate=2006-10-23 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20060630001109/http://www.cdns.com.tw/20051004/news/tyxw/800070002005100317462571.htm |archivedate = 2006-06-30}} #{{note|name3}} {{cite web|title=Âè∞‰∏≠Êñ∞Ê£íÁêÉÂ†¥ÂïüÁî® Êõ¥ÂêçÁÇ∫Ê¥≤ÈöõÊ£íÁêÉÂ†¥ (Taichung's new baseball stadium will change name to Intercontinental Baseball Stadium)|url=http://sports.yam.com/special/ic2006/show.php?id=0000087032|date=October 20, 2006|accessdate=2006-10-25 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20061108035014/http://sports.yam.com/special/ic2006/show.php?id=0000087032 |archivedate = 2006-11-08}} #{{note|ITA-AUS}} {{cite web|url=http://www.baseball.ch/TPE06/bxscores/16.htm|title=Italy v. {{Infobox venue |stadium_name = Tiger Stadium |location = 3701 W [[Texas State Highway 22|State Highway 22]], [[Corsicana, Texas]] |coordinates = {{Coord|32|05|11|N|96|30|57|W|type:landmark|display=inline,title}} |image =
[[Image:Corsicana Tiger Stadium.jpg|250px]] |caption = |built = 2004‚Äì2006http://www.corsicanadailysun.com/archivesearch/local_story_167093731.html |opened = September 15, 2006 |owner = [[Corsicana Independent School District]] |seating_capacity = 10,001 |surface = [[FieldTurf]] |construction_cost = [[United States Dollar|$]]18 million http://www.corsicanadailysun.com/archivesearch/local_story_257101657.html |tenants = [[Corsicana Independent School District|Corsicana High School]] (2006‚Äìpresent)
[[Navarro College]] (2006‚Äìpresent)
[[Corsicana Bowl]] (2017‚Äì)}} '''Tiger Stadiumhttp://www.texasbob.com/stadium/stadium.php?id=1042''' is a 10,001-capacity high school and junior collegiate [[American football]], [[track and field]] and [[soccer]] stadium adjacent to Corsicana High School in [[Corsicana, Texas]]. It is the current home of the Corsicana Tigers football, track and field, and soccer teams, the [[Navarro College]] Bulldogs football team, and the [[Corsicana Bowl]], a [[NCAA Division II]] College Football [[Bowl Game]]. ==History== The sports complex began its history as part of a larger $44.5 million bond project that was passed in 2004 to enlarge the high school, renovate and expand [[Corsicana Independent School District|Collins Middle School]] and improve facilities for sports and other extracurricular activities at both schools. Tiger Stadium sits on about {{convert|30|acre|m2}} of a {{convert|116|acre|km2|adj=on}} site bought by the [[Corsicana Independent School District]] in 2004 in anticipation of the new stadium. Tiger Stadium replaces Tiger Field, which opened in 1961, as the home for the Corsicana Tigers and Navarro College Bulldogs. The stadium has not only hosted games for the main tenants, but has also recently been used as a neutral site along with other newer high school, collegiate and professional stadiums in [[Texas]] in the [[University Interscholastic League|University Interscholastic League's]]http://www.corsicanadailysun.com/archivesearch/local_story_318033544.html annual Texas State Football Playoffs. ==Timeline== *2004: Corsicana I.S.D. passes a $44.5 million bond project to enlarge the high school, renovate and expand Collins Middle School, and improve all sports and extracurricular facilities. CISD also purchases a {{convert|116|acre|km2|adj=on}} site adjacent to the high school and Navarro County Exposition Center in anticipation to build a new multi-sport complex. Construction begins on the stadium, parking lots, and field house. *September 2006: Main construction on Tiger Stadium is completed, all subvarsity home games prior to September 15, 2006 were played at Tiger Field to allow Corsicana High the honors of playing the first game in the stadium. *September 15, 2006: Corsicana High lost to Waco High 34‚Äì10 in the first high school football game played at Tiger Stadium.http://www.hsgametime.com/sharedcontent/dws/spt/highschools/leaderboard/football/2006/schedules/HSFB-teamskeds-1108.html *September 16, 2006: Navarro College lost to Kilgore College 27‚Äì16 in the first collegiate football game played at Tiger Stadium.http://www.corsicanadailysun.com/archivesearch/local_story_262101821.html *November 18, 2006: Crockett High defeats Mexia High 49‚Äì12, in the first high school football playoff game played at Tiger Stadium. The game was a Class 3A, Division 2, Region 3, Bi-district playoff game in the first round of the 2006 Texas High School Football Playoffs.http://www.uil.utexas.edu/athletics/archives/football/playoff_brackets/06_07/3A_bracket/3A_division2.html *December 2, 2017: The inaugural [[Corsicana Bowl]] was held. [[Central Oklahoma Bronchos football|Central Oklahoma]] defeated [[Tarleton State Texans football|Tarleton State]] 38 to 31. http://newsok.com/uco-beats-tarleton-state-in-corsicana-bowl/article/5574499 ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.texasbob.com/stadium/stadium.php?id=1042 TexasBob.com ‚Äì Tiger Stadium ‚Äì Corsicana, Texas] {{s-start}} {{succession box | title = Home of the
[[Corsicana Independent School District|Corsicana Tigers]] | years = 2006 ‚Äì present | before = Tiger Field | after = current }} {{succession box | title = Home of the
[[Navarro College]] Bulldogs | years = 2006 ‚Äì present | before = Tiger Field | after = current }} {{succession box | title = Home of the
[[Corsicana Bowl]] | years = 2017 ‚Äì present | before = NONE | after = current }} {{s-end}} [[Category:College football venues]] [[Category:High school football venues in Texas]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Navarro County, Texas]] [[Category:Athletics (track and field) venues in Texas]] [[Category:Soccer venues in Texas]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2006]]
